Thus, RSA can go beyond classiﬁcation to test speciﬁc alternative models of the dimensions that structure the representation of others’ emotions.  Candidate Feature Spaces for Emotion Inference Research in affective neuroscience has typically examined representations involved in both ﬁrst-person emotional experience and emotional face perception. Here, we address a different question, concerning observers’ inferences about others’ emotions. Nevertheless, it is plausible that intuitive theories of emotion are fairly veridical (in order to be maximally useful in social interactions) and even informed by one’s own emotional experiences. Therefore, models of the structure of ﬁrst-person emotional experience may also capture the basis for third-person emotion attribution. We drew from prior literature on emotional experience three alternative models of the representational space of emotions.  A dominant approach has been to represent emotions as combinations of more basic affective states. According to basic emotion theory, complex and subtle emotions can be understood as combinations of 5–6 basic emotional states, each associated with a prototypical facial expression and innate neural substrate [1, 20, 21]. A second theory is the ‘‘circumplex’’ model, which posits that emotions are composed of only two primitive  dimensions—valence and arousal [9, 22, 23]—corresponding to two innate systems implemented in distinct neural circuits and recruited to varying degrees across different emotions [24–26]. In this view, neural representations of emotion may be reduced to a linear combination of these two neurophysiological dimensions [27].  Although many have focused on the differences between these two proposals [28, 29], both aim to represent emotions in terms of combinations of a small number of basic affective states, rooted in innate neural substrates. An alternative approach in affective science, termed ‘‘appraisal theory,’’ aims to instead characterize emotions in terms of people’s interpretations or ‘‘appraisals’’ of the events around them [30, 31]. Researchers have proposed speciﬁc sets of event appraisals that correspond to different emotions (see Supplemental Experimental Procedures for further details) and shown that these features capture differences in the emotions subjects experience across different situations [32, 33].  All three of these theories have shown some utility in characterizing ﬁrst-person emotional experiences. Here, we investigated whether any of these approaches successfully capture subjects’ intuitive attributions of others’ emotions and whether they could explain the representational spaces in MPFC and other ToM regions. If people reason about others’ emotions using an intuitive causal theory (embedded in a larger intuitive ToM), this theory should capture regularities in the situations that cause different emotions. Thus, we hypothesized that the representations involved in inferring the emotions of others, especially based on short verbal narratives, would be better captured by abstract event features than by combinations of basic emotional dimensions.  We therefore used RSA to determine whether representations in regions that discriminate our 20 categories are best captured by one of three candidate spaces (see Figure 2): a ‘‘circumplex’’ space deﬁned by independent subjects’ judgments (Amazon Mechanical Turk [MTurk]; see Supplemental Experimental Procedures) of valence and arousal for each stimulus, a ‘‘basic emotion’’ space deﬁned by judgments of the extent to which the stimulus elicited each of six basic emotions (happy, sad, angry, afraid, disgusted, or surprised), and a space of abstract event features derived from appraisal theory. For this third model, we generated a set of 38 event features thought to reliably vary across different emotion concepts (e.g., ‘‘Did someone cause this situation intentionally, or did it occur by accident?’’; See Supplemental Experimental Procedures for appraisal features and selection process). Importantly, the latter space differs from the other two not only in its dimensionality (38 dimensions versus 6 or 2) but also in its content: rather than reducing the space of emotions to a smaller set of purportedly ‘‘basic’’ affective states, it aims to encode emotions in terms of abstract features of the causal contexts that tend to elicit them. To test which feature space best explains the neural representation of these stimuli, we computed the similarity of emotion conditions within each proposed feature space and compared the RDMs of candidate models to neural RDMs derived from patterns of activity across voxels in each ROI.  Of course, the hypothesis that neural representations of emotion concepts are best captured by a high-dimensional space of abstract event features is not incompatible with the  1946 Current Biology 25, 1945–1954, August 3, 2015 ª2015 Elsevier Ltd All rights reserved  Figure 1. MPFC and other ToM regions in individual subjects (see Figure S1). We selected a subset of conditions that most closely align with the positive and negative conditions used previously [14] and tested whether neural patterns in MPFC would support decoding of valence. Replicating prior work, classiﬁcation of valence was reliably above chance in both DMPFC (M(SEM) = 0.610(0.028), t(19) = 3.889, p < 0.001) and MMPFC (0.603(0.019), t(19) = 5.530, p < 0.001).  claim that simpler dimensions like valence and arousal contribute to the organization of our emotion knowledge. For example, we included features such as goal consistency and pleasantness that intuitively relate to the dimension of valence. The question, then, is whether the representations in regions like MPFC can be exhausted by one of the simpler spaces. With this approach, we show that it is possible to characterize the ﬁne-grained representational structure of a high-level human reasoning capacity like emotion attribution.  RESULTS  Classiﬁcation In the scanner, subjects (n = 22) read 200 stimuli describing situations that would cause a particular emotion (see Experimental Procedures; example stimuli provided in Table 1). To conﬁrm that these stimuli elicit reliable ﬁne-grained emotion attributions, a group of subjects on MTurk were asked to choose which of 20 emotion labels best described the emotion of the character in each stimulus. These subjects performed well above chance (relative to the intended emotion), classifying the stimuli with 65% accuracy (chance = 5%; Figure 1C; see Supplemental Information for evidence that subjects attribute consistent emotions). This classiﬁcation accuracy provided a benchmark with which to compare different models and brain regions.  To identify regions in which neural patterns contain information about emotions, we ﬁrst replicated the ﬁnding that MPFC contains abstract emotion representations by testing whether neural patterns in MPFC could distinguish the valence in single trial estimates of these verbal stimuli. We functionally localized  We then investigated whether these or other regions contain information about the full set of 20 emotions. A whole-brain searchlight revealed that the set of regions that could reliably decode the 20 emotions was largely restricted to regions of the ToM network (particularly DMPFC, RTPJ, LTPJ; see Figure 1B and Table S1). The searchlight analysis exhibited striking overlap with the set of regions recruited for ToM (Figure 1B shows overlap between the searchlight [family-wise error, FWE p < .05, k > 25] and the random effects analysis of false belief > false photograph from the localizer task, shown at p < .001 uncorrected) and justiﬁed our continued focus on these a priori ROIs. Consistent with the searchlight results, we were able to classify emotions with above-chance accuracy (1 out of 20 emotions, 5%) based on neural patterns in all individually localized ToM regions (Figure 1A; Table S2). Because these analyses involved training and testing across stimulus items, above-chance classiﬁcation indicates a representation of emotion that generalizes across otherwise highly variable verbal scenarios.  Moreover, in the judgments provided by subjects on MTurk, there were reliable differences across the emotion categories in the extent to which subjects provided the expected emotion label (one-way ANOVA: F(19,180) = 4.99, p < 0.001; see Figure 1C), which provided another signature with which to compare neural representations. We computed separate accuracies for each emotion category in each ROI and correlated these with the behavioral emotion labeling accuracies. In all ROIs, the accuracy of neural classiﬁcations for different emotions was signiﬁcantly correlated with the accuracy levels observed in the emotion judgments of the MTurk behavioral raters (see Table S2; see Figure 1D). Thus, the reliable across-emotion accuracy differences observed behaviorally were paralleled in the emotion-speciﬁc  Current Biology 25, 1945–1954, August 3, 2015 ª2015 Elsevier Ltd All rights reserved 1947  Figure 2. RSA Representational similarity analyses were then used to test speciﬁc hypotheses about the structure of the representations in these regions. We generated three competing feature spaces using independent behavioral ratings (Figure 2A) and tested which feature space could best capture the neural representation of the 20 emotions. We ﬁrst analyzed the behavioral data alone, assessing the extent to which emotion categories could be reliably classiﬁed based on feature vectors in each of these candidate spaces. Speciﬁcally, we tested whether models trained on each of the feature vectors for a subset of stimuli could reliably classify the emotion label of untrained stimuli (see Supplemental Experimental Procedures). Do any of these feature spaces provide a stimulus representation sufﬁcient to match the performance of human subjects in discriminating these 20 emotions (65%)? We found that although all three feature spaces classiﬁed well above a chance level of 5%, the appraisal feature space outperformed the other lower-dimensional spaces (57%, compared to behavioral benchmark of 65%; see Figure 2B; note because we used cross-validated accuracy, this analysis is not biased by the dimensionality of the models). Using a paired samples t test across individual items, we found that the abstract appraisal space performed reliably better than the circumplex space (t(199) = 8.288, p < 0.001) and the basic emotion space (t(199) = 2.176, p = 0.031).  RDMs derived from these three feature spaces were then compared to neural RDMs in each region to identify the space that best accounts for the similarity of the emotion conditions in their neural patterns. Because the appraisal RDM could perform best simply because it better discriminates the 20 emotions, we compared its performance to that of a pure categorical  model and an RDM deﬁned from the behavioral confusion matrix (see Supplemental Experimental Procedures), both of which also successfully discriminate the emotions (Figure 3). We also tested a model in which condition similarity is deﬁned in terms of similarity of word-frequency vectors, a representation frequently used in fully automated approaches to emotional text classiﬁcation such as sentiment analysis of reviews or other social media [34, 35]. Does the appraisal space outperform a raw word-level representation of the stimuli? Finally, we tested three control spaces capturing possible lower-level dimensions: reading ease, syntactic complexity, and rated intensity (confounded with motor (see Supplemental Experimental Procedures).  response)  For each region, we correlated RDMs for the competing feature spaces to neural RDMs from individual ROIs (distances of the 20 emotions in their voxel-wise patterns). In the two MPFC subregions, the similarity of emotion conditions in voxellevel patterns was positively correlated with similarity in the space of 38 appraisal dimensions (group-level Kendall’s tau, DMPFC: 0.28; MMPFC: 0.21). Correlations with individual subject neural RDMs revealed a reliable relationship between the neural and model RDMs (see Table 2; Figure 4). In both DMPFC and MMPFC, the neural similarities were more correlated with the appraisal space than with either basic or circumplex spaces (see Table 3). In both regions, the appraisal RDM also outperformed the categorical and confusion spaces, suggesting that the superior performance of this model cannot be fully explained by its ability to better differentiate the 20 emotions. The appraisal space also outperformed the RDM deﬁned from word-token frequencies and the control spaces for reading ease, syntactic complexity, and intensity (see Table 3).  We conducted the same analyses in the remaining ToM regions (RTPJ, LTPJ, PC, RSTS, and VMPFC): neural representations in these ROIs were also reliably correlated with the  1948 Current Biology 25, 1945–1954, August 3, 2015 ª2015 Elsevier Ltd All rights reserved  Figure 3. RSA Methods Representational dissimilarity matrices (RDMs) encode the pairwise Euclidean distances between different emotions within each feature space. For each region, a neural RDM captures the pairwise Euclidean distances between different emotions in the patterns of activity elicited across voxels (DMPFC shown here). Feature spaces are ﬁt to the neural data by computing correlations between feature space RDMs and neural RDMs for each region in each subject. In addition to the three candidate theories, we also test confusion and categorical spaces. Given that the appraisal space best captures the distinctions between the 20 emotions, it could outperform simpler models simply by virtue of its superior emotion discrimination. To test this possibility, we compare the appraisal space to a pure categorical RDM, which assumes that all emotions are perfectly and equally discriminable. As a more conservative test, we compute the correlation between neural RDMs and the raw behavioral confusion matrix. Like the categorical model, this confusion RDM captures the distinctions between the 20 emotions but also encodes similarity between different emotions as reﬂected in the behavioral confusions. the appraisal space outperforms these two models, it suggests that the appraisal space ﬁts the neural data in virtue of the features rather than emotion discriminability alone.  If  appraisal space RDM (see Figure 4 for RTPJ; see Figure S3 for results from other ToM regions), and no region was reliably more correlated with the basic emotion or circumplex spaces. The 38-dimensional space outperformed competing spaces in all ToM regions except for VMPFC (where the best-performing space was the word-frequency representation). However, DMPFC and MMPFC were the only regions in which the highdimensional space signiﬁcantly outperformed all models.  Region Contributions We could reliably decode emotions in all ToM ROIs, and the appraisal space did the best job of capturing the neural similarity space in most regions. Is the same information represented redundantly, or might these regions contribute differently to the representation of emotions? When classifying only valence, a model trained with voxels from all ToM ROIs (M(SEM) = 0.581(0.016), t(21) = 4.942, p < 0.001) performed less well than a model trained only with voxels in DMPFC (58.1% relative to 61%). However, when classifying the full set of 20 emotions, a model trained with voxels from all regions outperformed any of the individual ROIs, raising the possibility of non-redundant information across ToM regions.  To test for possible representational differences across the ROIs, we ﬁrst used an iterative split-half reliability analysis (Supplemental Experimental Procedures). We found that neu ral RDMs in DMPFC and RTPJ were more correlated with themselves than (Mwithin = 0.178, with the other ROI Mbetween = 0.164, p < 0.001) and that this effect was not observed between MMPFC and RTPJ (Mwithin = 0.121, Mbetween = 0.123, p < 0.922). To further characterize potential non-redundancy, we explored whether the regions differed in the particular situation features they represent. Rather than compute separate RDMs for each of 38 appraisal features, we identiﬁed a reduced set of ten features that captured the most unique variance in behavioral ratings across items, using a stepwise regression approach (see Figures S2 and S4; Supplemental Experimental Procedures). We then computed the RDMs for this ten-dimensional space and also for each of the ten features individually and correlated each with the neural RDMs in different regions. The neural RDMs in all regions were reliably correlated with the RDM of the ten-feature space (see Table 2; Figure S4), which appears to capture much of the representational structure of the initial 38-dimensional space (Figure S2). Consistent with the results above, a repeatedmeasures ANOVA on the neural-model correlations for each feature (with ROI and feature as within-subjects factors) revealed a signiﬁcant ROI 3 feature interaction for the comparison of DMPFC and RTPJ (F(9,171) = 2.06, p = 0.036), but not between MMPFC and RTPJ (F(9,171) = 1.036, p = 0.414). Together, these results provide evidence that multiple ToM regions are involved in the attribution of emotion and that some of these regions may contribute unique information to the ﬁnal representational space that governs behavior. DISCUSSION  Decades of research in the science of emotion have aimed to characterize emotions in terms of some low-dimensional space of basic affective primitives [1, 23, 27, 36]. Behaviorally, we ﬁnd that a space of abstract event features, derived from work in appraisal theory [33], reliably outperforms these simpler spaces in discriminating the 20 different emotions in our stimuli. Consistent with previous reports [13, 14], we ﬁnd that neural representations in MPFC contain information about attributed emotions. Whereas prior studies focused on coarse distinctions (e.g., valence), we classify a set of nuanced emotions at abovechance levels. Moreover, by expanding to a rich space of eliciting situations, we are able to decode attributed emotions in all regions of the ToM network, and the searchlight results suggest that this information is largely restricted to these regions (particularly MPFC, RTPJ, and LTPJ).  Although these classiﬁcations are reliably above chance (5%), they are far from reaching the accuracy observed behaviorally (65%). This discrepancy between neural and behavioral classiﬁcation could arise because the population code in these regions is insufﬁcient to explain the behavior and/or because single trial estimates of fMRI data provide a noisy, blurred measurement of the underlying neural code. However, across different emotions, there are reliable correlations in the average accuracy of the neural populations and of independent behavioral ratings, providing support for the role of these regions in emotion attribution behaviors.  The present work also probes the underlying representational structure that supports emotion discrimination. Previous literature [12–14] is consistent with the possibility that MPFC codes a limited space of affective dimensions such as valence and/or arousal. Moreover, even in our neural classiﬁcation analyses, a region could support 20-way classiﬁcation at abovechance levels by coding only a single dimension or feature that varies across emotions. Using RSA, we ﬁnd not only that brain regions involved in ToM reasoning contain information about attributed emotions but also that this information is best captured by the high-dimensional space of event features.  In the majority of ToM regions, the similarity of emotion conditions in their voxel response patterns is most correlated with the similarity of the emotions in the space of appraisals. This result suggests a neural code that does not reduce to a simpler  set of distinctions, such as valence and arousal, and provides novel insight into the granularity of the emotion representations in MPFC and other ToM regions. Together, the data suggest that human emotion attribution is organized around abstract features of the causal context in which different emotions occur rather than the affective primitives that have dominated prior research.  A challenge for future work will be characterizing the scope and speciﬁcity of the neural representations in ToM regions. Do these neural populations contain representations speciﬁc to attributed emotion, coded within a space of emotion-relevant event features, or contain information in the form of domain-general semantic representations used in the service of emotion attribution? It is quite possible that these event representations function as intermediate features in the service of diverse inferential processes in addition to emotion attribution. Ultimately, successfully inferring emotions depends on a rich body of world knowledge, and neural populations speciﬁc to social cognition must interface with more general-purpose semantic systems. Characterizing information ﬂow within and between these different networks will be an important avenue for future research.  Characterizing Representational Spaces To characterize the feature space that governs representation of attributed emotion in the human brain, we draw on methods that have been fruitful in recent research on visual object recognition and object semantics, where researchers have tested a range of high-level and low-level features that could capture neural similarity of different objects [18, 37–39]. In one study, Mitchell and colleagues [38] coded object words in terms of co-occurrence with a set of verbs hypothesized to pick out relevant semantic dimensions (e.g., ‘‘manipulate,’’ ‘‘taste’’), a representation that was sufﬁcient to support neural classiﬁcation of untrained stimuli. Later work showed that a corpus-based co-occurrence space is outperformed by a space derived from behavioral ratings on a set of a priori object properties (e.g., is it alive?) [40]. The present research is most similar to this second approach, relying on behavioral ratings of a set of hypothesized event features. We show that is possible to generate candidate representational spaces for domains of high-level cognition such as emotion inference and to use these spaces to characterize patterns of activity in ToM brain regions.  it  The study of object representation has also made headway on understanding differences across regions and temporal stages [37, 39], with RSA in particular providing a ﬂexible framework for comparing the structure of the representations along the ventral pathway [41]. Interestingly, the present results provide preliminary evidence that ToM regions (particularly DMPFC versus RTPJ) may differ in their contributions to emotion inference. Further work is needed to characterize the precise computational roles of these regions and how they interact with other networks to form a processing stream.  As has been the case in research on object representation, we assume that future studies of emotion attribution will yield stimulus representations that outperform the 38-dimensional space explored here. Many early approaches to modeling neural object representations involved hand-picked features (e.g., 25 verbs)  1950 Current Biology 25, 1945–1954, August 3, 2015 ª2015 Elsevier Ltd All rights reserved  Figure 4. RSA Results Mean correlation (Kendall’s tau) between candidate model RDMs and individual subject neural RDMs (±SEM across subjects). Dotted line shows the noise ceiling (see Table S3).  proved useful in the present paradigm, it is unlikely that representations in domains of high-level cognition such as ToM can be reduced to operations over lists of associated features [45]. For example, an attributed emotion depends critically on the temporal and causal order of the different elements of the event (e.g., eating a whole cake and then swearing to keep to your diet versus swearing to keep your diet and then eating a whole cake). To capture the causal and compositional nature of emotion inference [4], future research may need to incorporate structured, generative knowledge representations from other areas of cognitive science [46]. The present ﬁndings lay groundwork for such research by providing an initial sketch of speciﬁc dimensions that might structure human emotion concepts and a framework for evaluating competing models of this knowledge.  [38] and often manual coding of stimuli within those spaces [37, 42]. However, recent research using high-throughput, datadriven approaches has yielded computational models that can be applied to raw stimuli (i.e., images) and achieve high quantitative ﬁt to neural patterns [43]. Here, candidate features were selected based on prior theories without subsequent optimization (this list may therefore contain redundant or uninformative features, and some additional features are likely necessary), and the stimuli required manual annotation (MTurk ratings). In fact, the model using 38 abstract event features falls short of human behavioral performance when labeling stimuli (57% versus 65% accurate), indicating that this collection of features does not completely capture intuitive emotion knowledge. A data-driven discovery method might be better able to capture the full range of relevant dimensions; future research would ideally identify new sets of optimized features (either event features or some other candidate basis) and ways to infer these features directly from text.  A second, more fundamental limitation is that this approach aims to encode human emotion knowledge in terms of lists of appraisal checks applied to each stimulus. While this ﬂat feature vector approach has been productive in other domains [44] and  Conclusions Despite important open questions, the present data provide novel insight into the representations underlying human emotion inference and the neural populations that support them. We show that it is possible to decode attributed emotions from neural patterns in regions involved in mental state reasoning and provide quantitative insight into the underlying representational structure that supports this inferential ability. Together, the results suggest that our knowledge of others’ emotions is abstract and high dimensional, that brain regions associated with emotion perception and inference contain information about relatively ﬁne-grained emotional distinctions, and that the neural representations in these regions are not reducible to more primitive affective primitives such as valence and arousal. Feature-Based Classiﬁcation of Behavioral Data To test whether any of the three candidate spaces (basic emotion, circumplex, and 38 appraisals) capture the full range of attributed emotions, we created an item-by-feature matrix for each possible space and tested whether a model (linear support vector machine [SVM]) trained on these features could classify the 20 distinct emotions (see Supplemental Experimental Procedures). We tested whether each feature space provided a basis for emotion discrimination that generalized across the different exemplars by using item-based crossvalidation folds and computing the average cross-item classiﬁcation accuracy for each feature space (comparing to the behavioral benchmark: 65%).  fMRI Emotion Attribution Task In the emotion attribution task, subjects viewed 200 emotion stimuli, along with ten stories describing physical pain [47]. The experiment consisted of ten runs (7.37 min/run), each containing one exemplar for each of 21 trial types (20 emotion conditions, 1 pain). Each story was presented at ﬁxation for 13 s, followed by a 2 s window for a behavioral response. Subjects were instructed to press a button to indicate the intensity of the character’s experience (1 to 4, neutral to extreme), which focused subjects’ attention on the character’s emotional state but ensured that behavioral responses (intensity) were orthogonal to discriminations of interest. The stories were presented in a jittered, event-related design, with a central ﬁxation cross presented between trials at a variable inter-stimulus interval of 3-5-7 s. The order of conditions was counterbalanced across runs and participants, and order of individual stories for each condition was randomized.  fMRI Analyses Acquisition and preprocessing details are provided in Supplemental Experimental Procedures.  MPFC could reliably classify the valence of these stimuli. We then tested whether voxel patterns in MPFC or other ToM regions could reliably classify the set of 20 emotions.  We conducted MVPA within ROIs that were functionally deﬁned based on individual subject localizer scans (including a ToM network ROI deﬁned as the union of each subject’s individually localized ROIs). We computed a single voxel pattern for each individual trial by averaging the preprocessed bold images for the trial and Z scoring relative to the mean across all trial responses in each voxel. The data were classiﬁed using a support vector machine; this classiﬁer uses condition-labeled training data to learn a weight for each voxel, and subsequent stimuli can then be assigned to one of two classes based on a weighted linear combination of the responses in each voxel. For the 20-way discrimination, multi-class classiﬁcation was conducted with a one-versusone method [48]. Classiﬁcation accuracy was averaged across ten cross-validation folds to yield a score for each subject per ROI, assessed with a onesample t test (one tailed) over individual accuracies (comparing to chance: 0.5 for positive versus negative; 0.05 for 20-way classiﬁcation). See Supplemental Experimental Procedures for further details.  RSA To create RDMs for the competing representational spaces, we ﬁrst averaged the feature vectors (from MTurk ratings) for each emotion condition (across stimuli), yielding the emotion-by-feature matrices shown in Figure 2. For each matrix, we then computed the Euclidean distance of feature vectors for each pair of emotions. We conducted this analysis iteratively (n = 1,000) across split halves of the data (ﬁve items per condition in each half), such that the selfdistances along the diagonal are meaningful. In addition to the ﬁve candidate feature spaces (circumplex, basic emotions, appraisals, confusions, and categorical), we generated an additional space deﬁned in terms of the similarity in word occurrences across stimuli, as well as additional control spaces to conﬁrm that neural RDMs could not be explained in terms of lower-level properties of the stimuli: reading ease, syntactic complexity, and behavioral ratings of intensity (Supplemental Experimental Procedures).  Neural RDMs were computed separately for each region in each subject with the same procedure as for feature space RDMs, except that features were voxel-wise neural responses rather than behavioral ratings (see Supplemental Information). We computed similarity of the conditions (Euclidean distance) in their voxel patterns (conducted across even and odd subsets so that the diagonal is interpretable), yielding an RDM for each region. To compare neural and model similarity spaces, we then computed the rank correlation (Kendall’s tau-a) between the model and neural RDMs for each region in each subject and compared these correlations to chance (average Kendall’s tau = 0) with a Wilcoxon test. We also compared the ﬁt of different models by conducting a one-tailed Wilcoxon signed-rank test on the correlations for different pairs of models. Luan Phan, Daniel A. Fitzgerald, Pradeep J. Nathan, Gregory J. Moore, Thomas W. Uhde, and Manuel E. Tancer  Background: Successful control of affect partly depends on the capacity to modulate negative emotional responses through the use of cognitive strategies. Although the capacity to regulate emotions is critical to mental well-being, its neural substrates remain unclear. Methods: We used functional magnetic resonance imaging to ascertain brain regions involved in the voluntary regulation of emotion and whether dynamic changes in negative emotional experience can modulate their activation. Fourteen healthy subjects were scanned while they either maintained the negative affect evoked by highly arousing and aversive pictures (e.g., experience naturally) or suppressed their affect using cognitive reappraisal. In addition to a condition-based analysis, online subjective ratings of intensity of negative affect were used as covariates of brain activity. Results: Inhibition of negative affect was associated with activation of dorsal anterior cingulate, dorsal medial prefrontal, and lateral prefrontal cortices, and attenuation of brain activity within limbic regions (e.g., nucleus accumbens/extended amygdala). Furthermore, activity within dorsal anterior cingulate was inversely related to intensity of negative affect, whereas activation of the amygdala was positively covaried with increasing negative affect. Conclusions: These findings highlight a functional dissociation of corticolimbic brain responses, involving enhanced activation of prefrontal cortex and attenuation of limbic areas, during volitional suppression of negative emotion.  Key Words: Amygdala, cognition, emotion, emotion regulation, fMRI, prefrontal cortex  H uman survival depends largely on the unique capacity to  perceive accurately and react appropriately to emotionally salient cues. It has been conjectured that emotions are based on motivational mechanisms that serve to guide adaptive behavioral responses (Darwin 1872/1965; James 1894). The most influential models of emotional processing posit that emotion is a transient, reflexive, and prepotent response to a salient, “exciting” stimulus that elicits a subjective affective experience (James 1894; Lazarus 1991). Animal, human neuropsychologic, and functional imaging studies provide partial support for the existence of a dedicated “emotion” circuit within the brain (Damasio 1994; Davidson and Irwin 1999; LeDoux 1996; Phan et al 2002). The amygdala, extended amygdala/ ventral striatum (including nucleus accumbens [NAcc]), insula, anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC), and orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) are often considered key neural substrates of this emotion processing circuit. Emotion processing not only involves detection and evaluation of salient stimuli, however, but also the experience and regulation of the subsequent affective response (Phillips et al 2003a). Delineating how these regions are involved in emotion regulation is important to advancing our understanding of the neural mechanisms of emotion and psychopathology (Phillips et al 2003b).  From the Department of Psychiatry (KLP, DAF), University of Chicago, Chicago, Illinois; Brain Sciences Institute (PJN), Swinburne University, Hawthorn, Australia; Departments of Psychiatry (GJM, TWU), and Radiology (GJM), Penn State University College of Medicine, Hershey, Pennsylvania; Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neurosciences (MET), Wayne State University School of Medicine, Detroit, Michigan.  Address reprint requests to K. Luan Phan, M.D., Department of Psychiatry, University of Chicago, 5841 South Maryland Avenue MC3077 (L-461), Chicago, IL 60637-1470; E-mail: luan@uchicago.edu.  Received June 4, 2004; revised October 11, 2004; accepted October 29, 2004.  0006-3223/05/$30.00 doi:10.1016/j.biopsych.2004.10.030  Immediate reactions to emotionally evocative stimuli are not always helpful, and thus the individual is required to engage in deeper interpretation of the salience of incoming information and modify emotions toward context-specific goals (Gross 1999). Indeed, in the face of negative events, we humans have the distinctive capacity to regulate our emotions to lessen and cope with distress. Negative emotions that are exaggerated or become dysregulated (or both) can lead to vulnerability toward pathologic anxiety and mood (Critchley 2003; Davidson 2002; Mayberg 2003). Preliminary evidence regarding the neurobiological basis of this adaptive process derives from studies in patients with prefrontal brain lesions (particularly in the ventral– orbital frontal cortex), which consequently manifest in affective instability and impulsive aggression (Damasio 1994; Davidson et al 2000; Nauta 1971). In addition, findings from the cognitive neurosciences have helped advance our understanding of the neural basis of affective regulation. The most influential neurobiological model for the cognitive control of behavior implicate the dorsal regions of the frontal cortex (dorsal ACC and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex [DLPFC]; Miller and Cohen 2001). For example, functional imaging of Go/No-Go and Stroop interference tasks that require subjects to restrain prepotent responses consistently show recruitment of dorsal ACC and DLPFC (Braver et al 2001; Garavan et al 2002; Konishi et al 1999). If emotional responses to salient stimuli can be regarded as reflexive in nature, then conscious attempts to regulate these responses may also engage brain regions generally responsible for cognitive control of behavior. imaging provides additional clues toward elucidating the neural correlates of cognitive influences on the emotion control. First, the mere presence of cognitive effort can both augment activity within dorsal frontal regions and attenuate limbic (e.g., amygdala) responses during emotional evocation (Hariri et al 2000; Liberzon et al 2000; Taylor et al 2003). Second, voluntary self-regulation of sexual (Beauregard et al 2001) and autonomic (Critchley et al 2002) arousal increases activity within the dorsal ACC while dampening activation of the amygdala (Beauregard et al 2001). Third, and more directly, two studies to date have examined the neural  Recently emerging evidence from functional  BIOL PSYCHIATRY 2005;57:210 –219 © 2005 Society of Biological Psychiatry  K.L. Phan et al  BIOL PSYCHIATRY 2005;57:210 –219 211  correlates of voluntary suppression of negative emotions. Ochsner and colleagues (2002) were the first to report that the use of cognitive strategies (e.g., reappraisal) to reframe stimuli that evoked negative feelings in unemotional terms evoked greater activation of dorsal ACC, dorsal MPFC (DMPFC), and DLPFC and suppressed activity in the amygdala and medial OFC. In a subsequent study by Levesque et al (2003), suppression of sadness (evoked by films) via an alternative cognitive strategy (e.g., detachment) resulted in activations within the right OFC, the DLPFC, and, less consistently, the dorsal ACC. Coupled with support from electrophysiologic and behavioral studies on emotion regulation (Gross 1999; Jackson et al 2000), these findings provide support for the feasibility of voluntary self-regulation of affective experience and of studying the neural basis of this process with brain imaging.  This study used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and employed a similar “emotion regulation” paradigm as that of Ocshner and colleagues (2002) to explore the neural substrates mediating voluntary suppression of negative emotion. We employed reliable probes of negative emotion and limbic activation (e.g., highly arousing and aversive pictures; Lang et al 1997; Phan et al 2002) and used a well-validated task in which subjects were trained either to maintain or suppress voluntarily their negative reactions during blocks of these evocative stimuli (Jackson et al 2000; Ochsner et al 2002). We sought to extend the prior findings by the inclusion of male participants, change of the design to a block (versus event-related) format, and analysis of brain activity in relation to subject-specific behavioral data. In particular, to account for intra- and interindividual differences in how well each subject regulated their affective state, we acquired online subjective ratings of intensity of negative emotion following each block and used these ratings as parametric covariates in our subsequent analysis (Phan et al 2003; Winston et al 2002). Based on prior findings on cognitive control and emotion processing in general, we predicted that volitional inhibition of negative emotion would enhance activity within discrete cortical structures (dorsal ACC, DLPFC, OFC) and attenuate activity within subcortical (amygdala, extended amygdala) and paralimbic (insular cortex) brain regions. Consequently, these areas represented regions of interest (ROIs) in our statistical analysis.  Methods and Materials  Subjects  Fourteen healthy, right-handed subjects (6 men, aged 22–38 years, mean 27.6 ⫾ 4.4 years) participated in the study. The participants had normal or corrected-normal vision and were without a history of psychiatric or neurologic illness, as verified by a semistructured clinical interview. All subjects gave written informed consent after explanation of the experimental protocol, as approved by the Wayne State University School of Medicine’s Human Investigation Committee.  Stimuli and Behavioral Protocol  The stimulus set consisted of 40 highly aversive and arousing pictures based on normative ratings from the International Affective Picture System (IAPS; Lang et al 1997) and five blank (BL) gray-scale images with a centered fixation cross. The mean (⫾ SD) valence and arousal values on a 9-point scale for the pictures were 2.03 ⫾ .44 and 6.03 ⫾ .72, respectively (1 ⫽ most unpleasant/least arousing, 9 ⫽ most pleasant/most arousing). The pictures were transformed to gray-scale using Adobe Photoshop 7 (Adobe Systems, San Jose, California). The pictures  elicit both evaluation and experience of negative affect (Lang et al 1993) and generally depict complex scenes of burn victims, funeral scenes, people crying, and dead animals. Of note, the pictures selected for the two experimental conditions (described later) were matched for general content, including faces and figures, and were balanced on subjective valence and arousal (t test, p ⬎ .5). Prior studies have demonstrated the reliability of these emotionally salient pictures to consistently evoke negative emotions and activations in limbic and paralimbic brain regions (Phan et al 2002). Stimuli were presented through magneticresonance-compatible liquid crystal display goggles (Resonance Technology, Northridge, California).  The emotion regulation protocol employed two main conditions of interest, Maintain or Suppress, serving as control and experimental tasks, respectively. On Maintain (M) blocks, subjects were instructed to attend to, be aware of, and experience naturally (without trying to change or alter) the emotional state elicited by the pictures; they were told to maintain the evoked affect for the entire block. On Suppress (S) blocks, subjects were instructed to decrease voluntarily the intensity of their negative affect by using the cognitive strategy of reappraisal (Gross 1999; originally pioneered by the work of Lazarus 1991), which is to reinterpret the content of the picture so that it no longer elicited a negative response. During the hour prior to scanning, participants received extensive instruction on cognitive reappraisal from a trained psychiatrist (KLP). Two main examples of cognitive reappraisal were provided to facilitate understanding of the strategy: 1) transforming the scenario depicted into positive terms (e.g., women crying outside of a church could be alternatively interpreted as expressing tears of joy from wedding ceremony rather than of sorrow from a funeral) and 2) rationalizing or objectifying the content of the pictures (e.g., a woman with facial bruises could be translated as an actor wearing makeup rather than a victim of domestic abuse). Pilot testing in our and other laboratories (Jackson et al 2000; Ochsner et al 2002) have suggested that these two types of reappraisal strategies are frequently used and often successful in volitional suppression of the negative emotions evoked by aversive IAPS pictures. Although we provided examples for illustrative purposes, we informed subjects that no single type of reinterpretation was universally applicable to all pictures, as in real life, and that they were to use the most effective reframing strategy for each picture. The training session included interactive instruction with the psychiatrist to ensure that subjects could reappraise the pictures quickly and effectively as well as practice trials with sample aversive pictures (not shown during scanning). Participants were instructed not to look away (unless necessary) or distract themselves with irrelevant thoughts. Subjects confirmed their understanding of the instructions and reappraisal strategy prior to scanning, as evidenced by their ability to provide explicit, detailed verbal descriptions of the techniques they would use to modulate their emotional experience.  Participants were scanned while performing the following behavioral protocol (Figure 1). Subjects viewed 20-sec blocks of aversive pictures; each picture was presented for 4 sec consecutively without an interstimulus interval. Prior to each block of pictures, the instruction to “MAINTAIN” or “SUPPRESS” appeared at the center of a gray screen below a fixation cross for a duration of 4 sec (Instruction). Immediately following each Maintain and Suppress block, a blank screen with a rating scale appeared for 4 sec asking participants to rate candidly the intensity of their negative affect on a 5-point scale (1 ⫽ least negative/neutral, 5 ⫽ extremely negative) via button response by pressing the button  www.elsevier.com/locate/biopsych  212 BIOL PSYCHIATRY 2005;57:210 –219  K.L. Phan et al  Figure 1. Exemplar segment of the behavioral paradigm for emotion regulation. Salient emotional pictures are presented in 20-sec blocks, preceded by instructions to “Maintain” or “Suppress” the evoked affect. Following each block, the subject provided a rating of the intensity of their negative emotional state.  1–5 times (Rating). This was followed by a 20-sec baseline block of blank fixation images (4 sec each) to minimize carryover effects (Baseline, B). During this period, subjects were asked to stop maintaining or suppressing their emotional experience and to “relax and clear your mind.” The order of Maintain and Suppress epochs was presented in a pseudo-randomized order over two separate sessions, which were counterbalanced across subjects.  Image Acquisition  Functional MRI was performed on a 1.5-T Sonata scanner (Siemens Medical Systems, Erlangen, Germany) to acquire BOLD (blood oxygenation level– dependent) contrast using single-shot multi-echo T2*-weighted EPI (echoplanar imaging) with six evenly spaced echo times ranging from 18 to 93 msec (repetition time ⫽ 2000 msec; 192 mm field of vision, 32 ⫻ 32 matrix, 16 slices, 6-mm slice thickness, .6-mm slice gap; flip angle ⫽ 90°; Posse et al 1999). Slices were oriented axially or near axially along the AC-PC line. The first four volumes from each run were discarded to allow for T1 equilibration effects. Additionally, a T1-weighted high-resolution structural scan was acquired in each subject for subsequent anatomic localization. Head movement was minimized using a custom-fitted head holder, consisting of two-component polyurethane foam tightly molded around the head and neck.  Image Analysis  Data sets from all 14 subjects met our criteria for high quality and scan stability with minimum motion correction (⬍ 2 mm displacement in any one direction) and were subsequently included in fMRI analyses. Image processing and data analysis was performed using the statistical parametric mapping software package SPM99 (Wellcome Department of Cognitive Neurology, London; www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm). Standard pre-processing was applied comprising slice time correction, realignment, and spatial normalization to the Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) high-resolution T1 template. Images were resampled into this space with 2-mm isotropic voxels and smoothed with a  www.elsevier.com/locate/biopsych  Gaussian kernel of 6-mm full-width at half-maximum to minimize noise and residual differences in gyral anatomy, resulting in an effective spatial resolution of 10.2 ⫻ 10.7 ⫻ 11.5 mm. Each normalized image was band-pass filtered (low-pass filter ⫽ canonical hemodynamic response function [HRF]; high-pass filter ⫽ 100 sec) to remove high- and low-frequency noise, respectively. The general linear model was applied from which statistical inferences were based on the theory of random Gaussian fields, and changes relative to the experimental conditions were modeled by convolution of boxcar epochs with the canonical HRF to approximate the activation patterns (Friston et al 1995). Using multiple regression analysis, we constructed statistical parametric maps (SPMs) representing the association between the observed time series (e.g., BOLD signal) and one or a linear combination of the regressors for each subject. The SPMs were derived for brain activity related to the following:  1. main effects of task for Suppress (S ⬎ B) and Maintain (M ⬎  B);  2. conjunction of effects across both Maintain and Suppress tasks versus baseline (e.g., [M ⬎ B] AND [S ⬎ B]) to identify regions that activate in both tasks in response to aversive picture blocks (Price and Friston 1997);  3. effect of Suppress versus Maintain (S ⬎ M) to identify regions with greater activity during voluntary suppression of negative emotion;  4. effect of Maintain versus Suppress (M ⬎ S) to identify regions with less activity during voluntary suppression of negative emotion;  5. negative correlation with intensity of negative emotion to identify regions in which activity was inversely related to negative affect; and  6. positive correlation with intensity of negative emotion to identify regions in which activity was associated with negative affect.  Of note, contrasts 1– 4 modeled brain activity only for the 20-sec blocks during which the pictures were presented and during the active task of Maintain or Suppress and did not  K.L. Phan et al  BIOL PSYCHIATRY 2005;57:210 –219 213  include the Instruction or Rating portions of the imaging run, thereby removing any influence on brain activity related to reading the instruction and generating the rating response, respectively. These analyses used two separate, complementary statistical approaches—a standard block-design analysis of taskdependent activation of two conditions of interest (M and S) identical for all subjects (contrasts 1– 4) and an individualized analysis of using the subjective ratings (e.g., subjects’ own online rating of their affect following each Maintain and Suppress block) as a covariate of brain activation (contrasts 5– 6; Phan et al 2003, 2004). This latter analysis serves as a complement to the standard condition-specific analysis (e.g., S ⬎ M) that uses an on– off “boxcar” regressor to model the expected hemodynamic response, specific to each condition. As previously described (Phan et al 2003, 2004), this analysis involved convolving the predicted height of the canonical HRF with a stepwise function using the subjective ratings as individualized regressors rather than the conventional boxcar regressor, identical for each subject. The affective ratings from each subject following each block were covaried with the BOLD response averaged across the entire block for each voxel across the entire brain. Thus the rating-specific regressors, taken from the 5-point emotional scale, varied in discrete steps and was intended to reflect within- and between-subject differences in affective experience following both Maintain and Suppress conditions across the entire imaging run, as well as serve as an index for the outcome (e.g., success or failure) of the emotion regulation strategies (Phan et al 2003). Subject-specific parameter estimates pertaining to each regressor were calculated at each voxel, and contrast images (SPMs) were calculated by applying appropriate linear contrasts to the parameter estimates. These contrasts images were then entered into a one-sample t test across the 14 subjects in a second-level, random-effects analysis to allow for inferences to the general population. This produced statistical parametric maps of the t statistic at each voxel, which were subsequently transformed to the Z distribution. From voxelwise comparisons, activation foci within a priori regions were considered significant with a height threshold of p ⬍ .005 uncorrected (t ⬎ 3.01), with an extent of at least 5 contiguous voxels. Predicted regions included the amygdala, extended amygdala/ventral striatum (including the NAcc), insula, ACC, MPFC, and LPFC, derived from prior independent observations of regional activation associated with cognitive influences on emotional processing (Beauregard et al 2001; Hariri et al 2000; Keightley et al 2003; Lange et al 2003; Levesque et al 2003; Ochsner et al 2002; Pessoa et al 2002; Schaefer et al 2002; Taylor et al 2003). These thresholds are commonly applied in the emotion imaging literature and were intended to strike a balance between type I and II error rates. Outside of a priori regions, we report activation foci above a p ⬍ .05, corrected for multiple comparisons across the entire brain.  Results  Behavioral Results  All subjects were debriefed following their scanning session and reported compliance with both “Maintain” and “Suppress” instructions. Each subject reviewed the pictures postscan, and none of the subjects reported having to close their eyes or resort to thinking irrelevant thoughts. Furthermore, they all reported that they were able to use the reappraisal strategies practiced before scanning; examples were provided by each subject to confirm their use of cognitive manipulation of the content of negative pictures. Most of the subjects did say, however, that  Figure 2. Subjective ratings of intensity of negative affect following each Maintain and Suppress block across the experiment. Signiﬁcant effect of condition but not of time or condition-by-time interaction.  some pictures (on average, fewer than 10%) were so aversive that attempts to reappraise them and suppress their negative response during the Suppress blocks were not entirely successful; of note, they reported that this was reflected in their subjective ratings of their negative affective state given after each block. As expected, the intensity of negative emotion was higher following the Maintain block than the Suppress block (Mean rating ⫾ SD: 4.27 ⫾ .33 vs. 1.95 ⫾ .70, respectively; t (13) ⫽ 11.30, p ⬍ .001). A repeated-measures analysis of variance (ANOVA) did not reveal a significant effect of time or time by condition interaction (p ⬎ .5). In identifying which brain regions were differentially activated between tasks, a direct contrast (contrast 4) between Suppress and Maintain blocks showed greater activity in the DMPFC (BA 8), dorsal ACC (BA 32), DLPFC (BA 9), lateral OFC (BA 11), and VLPFC (BA 46)/inferior frontal gyrus (including Broca’s area [BA 44]) during Suppress relative to Maintain condition (Table 1, Figure 3). In contrast, greater activity was  observed in the left NAcc, left LPFC (BA 46), and left sublenticular/periamygdala area during Maintain relative to Suppress (Table 1, Figure 3).  To examine the interaction between prefrontal and limbic regions, we focused on the relationship in brain activation between the left amygdala, observed to be activated during both Suppress and Maintain, and the prefrontal regions that were differentially activated during Suppress (vs. Maintain). To do this, we extracted the raw BOLD signal time series/courses from the peak activation foci/voxel within each of these regions (DMPFC, dorsal ACC, DLPFC, VLPFC, OFC; see Table 1) and from the left amygdala ([–18, – 4, –20]); these regions served as our functional regions of interest (ROIs). From the raw BOLD signal values, we calculated percent BOLD signal change during Suppress and Maintain blocks (vs. Baseline) averaged across each condition for each subject. We then performed a correlation analysis of these values between the ROIs. Of the prefrontal ROIs, only the right VLPFC (BA 47: [34, 54, 12]) showed a significant negative correlation with left amygdala (Pearson r ⫽ –.466, p ⫽ .01); there were no significant positive correlations detected.  Activation Related to Emotional Experience (Contrast 5– 6). The response in dorsal ACC (BA 24/32), bilateral DLPFC (BA 8), right anterior insula, and bilateral VLPFC (BA 46/10) was inversely related to the intensity of negative emotion (Table 2). Thus, increasing activity in these specific frontal regions was associated with decreasing negative affect (Figure 3). In contrast, activity in occipital cortex (BA 17–19), left DLPFC (BA 9), right VLPFC (BA 46) cortex, and left amygdala were positively correlated with intensity of negative emotion (Figure 4). Thus, increasing activity in these regions was associated with increasing intensity of negative affect.  Discussion  This fMRI study of emotion regulation is one of the first to examine the neural substrates involved in the voluntary suppression of negative affect and the relationship between these substrates and subjective, individual emotional experience. Several findings emerged that both extend and are consistent with recent observations from similar studies on the functional neuroanatomy of emotion regulation (Beauregard et al 2001; Levesque et al 2003; Ochsner et al 2002). Across both tasks, negatively valenced pictures evoked general activation of the primary visual cortex (BA 17), bilateral insula, bilateral amygdala, and MPFC. Activation of DMPFC (BA 9), dorsal ACC (BA32), and bilateral OFC (BA11), DLPFC (BA 9, and VLPFC [BA 46/47]/ inferior frontal gyrus (including Broca’s Area [BA 44]) was specifically observed during Suppress condition (relative to Maintain). In contrast, activity during left NAcc, left LPFC (BA 46), and left sublenticular/periamygdala area was selectively greater during Maintain relative to Suppress. Activity within left VLPFC (BA 47) was negatively correlated with that within left amygdala. Furthermore, our findings show that activation of the dorsal ACC (BA 24/32), bilateral DLPFC (BA 8), right anterior insula, and bilateral VLPFC (BA 46/10) was inversely related to the intensity of negative emotion, whereas activity in occipital cortex (BA 17–19), left DLPFC (BA 9), right VLPFC (BA 46) cortex, and left amygdala was positively correlated with intensity of negative emotion.  In response to evaluating and experiencing negatively valenced pictures, subjects recruited several limbic and paralimbic brain regions including the amygdala, anterior insula, MPFC, and primary visual cortex, as confirmed by our main effects and conjunction analyses. The amygdala, insula, and MPFC have been consistently implicated as key components of the neural circuit involved in the detection of emotional significance and in the generation of negative affective states (Davidson and Irwin 1999; George et al 1995; Pardo et al 1993; Phan et al 2002; Reiman et al 1997) in response to emotional faces (Morris et al 1996; Phillips et al 1997; Whalen et al 1998), pictures (Irwin et al 1996; Lane et al 1997b; Reiman et al 1997; Taylor et al 2000), and recall of personal life events (Damasio et al 2000; Lane et al 1997a; Liotti et al 2000). The amygdala, insula, and MPFC have together been implicated as playing general roles during emotional processing (for reviews, see Davidson and Irwin 1999; Phan et al 2002; Phillips et al 2003a). These regions may be responding to the negative pictures present during both tasks and are involved in general in evaluation and responding to emotionally salient  stimuli, generation of emotional responses, and awareness of internal emotional states. Of note, conjunction analysis revealed left, but not right, activation of the amygdala during both Suppress and Maintain tasks, and we interpret that the presence of highly negatively valenced pictures, present across both tasks, may have driven the left-lateralization. We note, however, that the linguistic/verbal nature of the tasks, conscious perception and evaluation of the sensory stimuli, lack of habituation, the chosen significance threshold, or a combination of these may also have contributed to the left-lateralization of amygdala activation (Wager et al 2003; Zald 2003).  Voluntary suppression of negative affect by cognitive reappraisal recruited several frontal regions including DMPFC, dorsal ACC, DLPFC, VLPFC, and OFC. This finding is consistent with several converging lines of evidence from affective neuroscience that have provided support the role of dorsal frontal cortex (dorsal ACC and DMPFC) and OFC in emotion regulation. Our findings support and extend prior observations of the prior fMRI study by Ochsner and colleagues using a similar emotion regulation strategy (Ochsner et al 2002). In that study, affective modulation by reappraisal was also associated with increased activation of the lateral and medial prefrontal cortices. In another study by Levesque et al (2003), suppression of sadness via an alternative cognitive strategy (e.g., detachment) resulted in activations within the right OFC, the DLPFC, and, less consistently, the dorsal ACC. Interestingly, other indirect observations of emotion regulation have implicated dorsal ACC, DMPFC, VLPFC, and/or OFC in voluntary control of physiologic arousal (Critchley et al 2002), inhibition of sexual arousal (Beauregard et al 2001), and in cognitive modulation of emotional responses by appraisal or labeling of stimulus salience (Hariri et al 2000; Lange et al 2003; Taylor et al 2003). In support, experiments in rodents have suggested that ablation of MPFC and OFC interferes with extinc Figure 4. Main effect of emotion ratings (inverse relationship between activation and intensity of negative emotion in blue; direct relationship between activation and intensity of negative ratings in orange; p ⬍ .005, uncorrected) overlaid on a canonical three-dimensional Montreal Neurological Institute brain rendering, as implemented with MRIcro software (C. Rorden and M. Brett: http://www.psychology.nottingham.ac.uk/staff/cr1/ mricro.html). Activation of dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) related to decreasing negative affect and activation of left amygdala (Amyg) related to increasing negative affect.  www.elsevier.com/locate/biopsych  216 BIOL PSYCHIATRY 2005;57:210 –219  K.L. Phan et al  tion of conditioned fear responses (Morgan and LeDoux 1995) and that the MPFC is critically involved in the inhibition of conditioned fear (Garcia et al 1999; Milad et al 2004; Quirk et al 2003), and human lesions in these regions produce syndromes characterized by impulsivity, poor behavioral control, and instability in affective responses (Damasio 1994; Davidson et al 2000). Collectively, these findings provide growing support for the dorsal ACC, DMPFC, VLPFC, and OFC in the regulation of affective states.  A major limitation to our study design and interpretation of findings involves the absence of stimuli with other types of valence, such as positive or pleasant pictures or neutral pictures, therefore, the activations during reappraisal may not be specific to changes in negative affect. In other words, frontal regions engaged during Suppress may have been related to more general reappraisal, independent of valence or evoked affect. Recent published imaging studies on emotion regulation that that have included a neutral condition (none to date have employed a paradigm involving reappraisal of positively-valenced stimuli) have presented similar findings (Levesque et al 2003; Ochsner et al 2002). Nevertheless, activation in these prefrontal regions can be mutually attributed to more general cognitive processes (versus down-regulation of negative emotion specifically). These same regions are commonly activated across cognitive tasks that involve inhibiting prepotent response tendencies (e.g., Go/NoGo, Stroop interference) (Braver et al 2001; Garavan et al 2002) and are implicated in neurobiological models of executive or cognitive control of behavior (Carter et al 2000; Miller and Cohen 2001). If emotional responses to salient stimuli can be conceptualized as reflexive (LeDoux 1996), attempts to manipulate them may engage executive processes that involve processes that exert voluntary control over behavior. Therefore, as previously proposed by Ochsner and colleagues (2002), an overlapping set of prefrontal regions that are involved in cognitive control may also be generally engaged during reappraisal, cognitive processing (e.g., attention, executive function, working memory, etc.), or, specifically, involved in the cognitive suppression of emotion. In our study, subjects were instructed to attend to and actively generate, modify/update, and keep in mind effective strategies for reappraising a diverse set of visually complex, unpleasant stimuli, as well as to mediate the competition between top-down (e.g., voluntary suppression) and bottom-up (e.g., evoked emotions) processes. Therefore, we would expect that such complex executive processes employing different types of cognitive processes would use the same brain regions involved in working memory such as the DLPFC and VLPFC and in selective attention and resolving response conflicts or interference such as the dorsal ACC (Cabeza and Nyberg 2000; Carter et al 2000; Miller and Cohen 2001). We would argue that such processes are inherently involved during emotion regulation. In future studies, more sophisticated designs with individual trials or events and task-switching paradigms may be able to clarify this important issue.  We did note that the lateral prefrontal cortex (BA 46) was also activated in the Maintain ⬎ Suppress contrast, suggesting that the DLPFC may have a role in different levels of emotion regulation (e.g., maintenance and suppression). The observed LPFC Maintain-related activation was left-sided, whereas most of the lateral prefrontal activations associated specifically with Suppress were right-lateralized. Such lateralization have hint toward different roles for a similar region. Previous studies have shown that providing verbal labels to emotional states, stimuli, or events activates left lateral prefrontal cortex (Crosson et al 1999; Hariri  www.elsevier.com/locate/biopsych  et al 2003; Lange et al 2003), consistent with the processes involved in maintaining negative affect. In contrast, studies on voluntary behavioral inhibition (consistent with emotion suppression) have reported right-sided activations of the lateral prefrontal cortex (Bunge et al 2001; Garavan et al 1999; Konishi et al 1999). The possibility that the DLPFC may have differential roles during regulation of emotion is intriguing, however, and awaits further study.  this cognitive circuit could reflect  Our findings also show that increasing activity within the dorsal ACC, DLPFC, and VLPFC was not only associated with voluntary suppression of affect but was also correlated with decreasing intensity of negative affect. We suggest that increased recruitment of increasing effectiveness in emotion regulation. Particularly, the dorsal ACC has been proposed to play a critical role in monitoring and adjusting the ongoing need for additional cognitive control (Botvinick et al 2001; Kerns et al 2004). This interpretation is also consistent with findings from the study by Ochsner and colleagues, who also reported a positive correlation between dorsal ACC activity and a drop in negative affect (e.g., effective reappraisal). Increased levels of negative affect may also reflect reduced recruitment of top-down control mechanisms. Interestingly, Bishop and colleagues (2004) recently showed that states of high anxiety were associated with lower levels of ACC activity during the perception of threat-related stimuli. We also observed an inverse relationship between negative affect and insular activity (which was activated during both Maintain and Suppress); this is inconsistent with a number of previous studies on negative affect or emotion and arousal (Critchley et al 2001; Phan et al 2002; Phillips et al 1997). Although some evidence exists that the insula may also respond to positively valenced emotion insular activity is (Kuniecki et al 2003), inversely related to increasing intensity of negative affect is counter to our a priori hypothesis and requires further investigation.  the suggestion that  Our findings also show that voluntary suppression of affect via cognitive reappraisal can attenuate activity in brain regions responsible for evaluation and experience of negative affect or emotional salience, such as the nucleus accumbens and sublenticular/periamygdala (Liberzon et al 2003; Zink et al 2003). Given that amygdala proper was engaged during both tasks, we did not detect a difference in activity within the amygdala during Maintain (e.g., M ⬎ S). However, our regression analysis using individualized ratings was sensitive in detecting a relationship between increasing activity in the left amygdala and increasing intensity of negative affect (Phan et al 2003). These findings are consistent with proposed models for the NAcc, extended amygdala/SLEA, and amygdala’s role in monitoring and responding to emotional salience (Liberzon et al 2003; Phan et al 2003; Whalen et al 1998), including signals of threat (Morris et al 1996; Whalen et al 1998), extending the role of the NAcc beyond reward (Knutson et al 2001; Zink et al 2004). Furthermore, the direct relationship between amygdala activation and increasing negative affect may serve as indicator for subjectively perceived failure in voluntary modulation of emotional responses elicited by the highly aversive pictures. We have previously demonstrated that activity in the amygdala and extended amygdala (including the ventral striatum/NAcc) corresponds to individual ratings of emotional intensity (Phan et al 2003) and serves as a sensor for increasing emotional salience or threat. Similar to our study, Schaefer and colleagues (2002) have observed that active maintenance of negative emotion evoked by aversive pictures led to increased activation of the amygdala. Our findings are also  K.L. Phan et al  BIOL PSYCHIATRY 2005;57:210 –219 217  consistent with prior functional imaging studies on emotion regulation showing attenuation of amygdala activity by cognitive reappraisal of aversive pictures (Ochsner et al 2002), detachment from sad films (Levesque et al 2003), and attempted inhibition of sexual arousal (Beauregard et al 2001). Additionally, increased cognitive effort can also diminish activation of limbic regions. For example, emotional tasks that require additional cognitive demand also can modulate responses in the amygdala and extended amygdala (Hariri et al 2000; Phan et al 2002; Taylor et al 2003). Directing attention away from emotionally evocative stimuli can also attenuate amygdala activation (Keightley et al 2003; Pessoa et al 2002). We hypothesize that in our study, cognitive reappraisal (e.g., reframing into positive outlook, or rationalizing) may have indirectly averted attention from the negative aspects of the aversive pictures, and thereby resulted in decreased activation of amygdala and extended amygdala/NAcc. We note that dorsal ACC and amygdala had opposite relationships with intensity of negative affect, prompting the question of a potential reciprocal relationship between frontal regions exerting top-down cognitive control and subcortical limbic regions responding to emotional value, arousal, salience, or a combination of these. Our correlation analysis of BOLD signal change during Suppress and Maintain conditions between frontal cortical and limbic regions did reveal an inverse relationship between VLPFC (BA 47) and the left amygdala. We note, however, that our long block-related design (e.g., requiring averaging of BOLD signal data over the entire 20-sec block) and inclusion of only negative pictures limited our ability to test this functional interaction more explicitly. Furthermore, our main effects analysis showed activation of the amygdala during both Maintain and Suppress conditions, suggesting that the activity in the amygdala was task-independent and not modulated by reappraisal in this experiment. Activation of the amygdala during both tasks may be related to the fact that a negative affect was maintained during the imaging run because of the presence of only aversive pictures (e.g., no neutral or positive pictures were presented). Some evidence suggests, however, that the PFC may be responsible for modulating responses in limbic amygdala. Animal studies show that direct stimulation of prefrontal inputs inhibits neuronal firing in and affective responses mediated by the amygdala (Rosenkranz and Grace 2001; Rosenkranz et al 2003). Furthermore, medial and ventral prefrontal regions appear to have a direct influence on amygdala-mediated fear conditioning (Garcia et al 1999; Milad et al 2004; Morgan and LeDoux 1999; Quirk et al 2003). Human functional brain imaging studies have also reported reciprocal relations between the PFC (including medial and orbital regions) and amygdala (Abercrombie et al 1998; Hariri et al 2003; Liberzon et al 2002). More specifically, recent studies have demonstrated the role of VLPFC (BA 47) in exerting cognitive or inhibitory influences on emotional and limbic (e.g., amygdala) responses (Hariri et al 2003; Keightley et al 2003; Lange et al 2003; Levesque et al 2003) and cognitive control in general (Konishi et al 1999). Additional studies will be needed to clarify both the process and interaction between PFC and amygdala during emotion regulation.  Before concluding, several limitations of the study are worth discussion. First, the study design limits conclusive inferences about the prefrontal, including dorsal ACC, activation and successful inhibition of negative affect. Given the preliminary nature of these findings, we would advise caution in interpreting the subjective ratings as a direct measure of efficacy or reappraisal success. Because ratings were not collected after each picture (e.g., trial) within the Suppress block, it could be argued that the  decrease in negative ratings following Suppress is a result of perceiving the pictures as less aversive rather than the result of reappraisal. We did not collect any physiologic data (e.g., skin conductance, startle response, etc.) during scanning and relied solely on subjective reports with ratings, which may be also be susceptible to bias. Nonetheless, the behavioral data on subjective ratings showed little change (e.g., no decrement) following the both Maintain and Suppress blocks over the course of the experiment (see Figure 2), suggesting that negative valence was maintained over time. Moreover, the participants subjectively reported that their chosen reappraisal strategies were generally effective in reducing negative affect and that their postblock ratings were candid measures of their emotional state. Furthermore, these findings are also consistent with prior work on emotion regulation and negative emotion (Levesque et al 2003; Ochsner et al 2002), which also depended on subjective measures. Similarly, we also relied on their postscan reports that they had used the reappraisal strategies established during extensive training when they were performing the task in the scanner. Second, although we used a conservative random-effects analysis of our fMRI data to protect against false positives, our small sample size may have introduced other errors; therefore, more conclusive evidence for a true absence of activation in certain brain areas awaits a larger cohort. Third, although our sample included an equal number of male and female subjects, having both genders may have added additional variability in our results given that gender differences can influence the brain’s response to negative stimuli and/or during emotion processing. For example, recent studies have shown that women have greater activation of the amygdala and ACC (Wrase et al 2003), prefrontal cortices (Kemp et al 2004) in response to negative stimuli; that men have greater amygdala activation to sexually arousing stimuli (Hamann et al 2004); and that gender can mediate lateralization of amygdala activation in relation to emotional faces (Killgore and Yurgelun-Todd 2001) and emotionally laden memory storage (Cahill et al 2001; Canli et al 2002). Finally, our study design lacked two components critical to a more complete understanding of the neural substrates of emotion regulation: 1) inclusion of positive valence or approach-related emotional stimuli (discussed earlier) and 2) voluntary enhancement of negative or positive emotion. Additional studies will be needed to further elucidate these important questions.  Conclusions  In conclusion, we present functional imaging evidence that the voluntary regulation of negative emotion by appraisal engages the dorsal anterior cingulate, medial prefrontal, and lateral prefrontal cortices, a neural circuit responsible for higher order executive functions such as cognitive control of behavior. We also showed that ongoing changes in intensity of negative affect during emotion regulation (e.g., relative success or failure) are mediated by activity within the dorsal ACC and amygdala, respectively. These findings shed light on the putative neural mechanisms for effective cognitive therapy for anxiety and mood disorders (Brody et al 1998, 2001; Mayberg 2003; Paquette et al 2003) and for general mental well-being (Gross 1999). Indeed, there now exists evidence for hypofunction of the dorsal ACC and MPFC or hyperactivity of the amygdala in the neural pathophysiology related to dysregulation of emotion such as anxiety (Bremner 2003; Davidson 2002; Shin et al 2004) and mood disorders (Drevets 2001; Lawrence et al 2004; Phillips et al 2003b; Sheline et al 2001). It is hoped that these and other recent findings will shed light on the cognitive, affective, and neural  www.elsevier.com/locate/biopsych  218 BIOL PSYCHIATRY 2005;57:210 –219  K.L. Phan et al  influences on voluntary regulation of emotion to advance our understanding of the mechanisms underlying mental illness and their therapeutic interventions.
