Error bars represent SEM.  c o r t e x 6 7 ( 2 0 1 5 ) 5 9 e7 3  65  However, some methodological limitations applied, as noted in section 1. Therefore, we would expect poorer self-face recognition performance in moderate AD patients than in matched controls. Moreover, previous studies (Hehman et al., 2005; Phillips et al., 1996) showed a temporally graded loss of self-face recognition in severe AD patients. Therefore, we would expect less accurate recognition of recent selfphotographs than of remote self-photographs in the moderate stages of AD.  In addition, to examine the neural correlates of face recognition in AD, resting-state fMRI was acquired in the moderate AD group. More speciﬁcally, we tested the correlation between the functional connectivity of key regions of the DMN [dorsal MPFC (dMPFC) and PCC], as assessed with resting-state fMRI, and face recognition scores (either familiar, self, or recent self faces) in AD patients. Considering that, in previous studies (Ries et al., 2012), attenuated functional connectivity between DMN regions was associated with less accurate self-appraisal scores in AD patients, our hypothesis was that a higher level of connectivity between DMN seed regions (dMPFC, PCC) and other DMN regions (intranetwork connectivity) would be associated with better selfand familiar-face recognition scores. Alternatively, higher connectivity levels between the DMN seeds and regions belonging to other resting-state networks (inter-network connectivity) might be linked to worse recognition scores, as AD patients have been shown to lose network segregation (Brier et al., 2012) and may be less efﬁcient at recruiting the appropriate networks.  Previous studies of aging had shown that upregulated activity in the prefrontal cortices was associated with poorer performance in word-retrieval tasks (Meinzer, Lindenberg, Antonenko, Flaisch, & Fl€oel, 2013) or language processing (Antonenko, Meinzer, Lindenberg, Witte, & Fl€oel, 2012). For the sake of completeness, we also analyzed connectivity in the occipito-temporal (ventral) pathway, which is involved in face processing per se, but we did not ﬁnd any signiﬁcant correlation with self and spouse face processing in our AD population, so this will not be reported in the results section.  3.1.  Method  Participants  3.1.1. Patients and healthy older controls were recruited with the same criteria as in experiment 1. Twenty-ﬁve patients (15 women) in the moderate stage of AD, as indicated by an MMSE score between 10 and 21 (Folstein et al., 1975), participated in this study. Twenty-ﬁve healthy older controls (15 women) were selected to match the AD patients according to their age [t(48) ¼ 1.07, p ¼ .29], number of years of education [t(48) ¼ ␀1.42, p ¼ .16] and gender. The AD patients had lower MMSE scores than the matched controls [t(48) ¼ ␀22.77, p < .01]. Moreover, MMSE scores of AD patients in this experiment was lower than those of AD patients in experiment 1 [t(44) ¼ 13.17, p < .01]. Ethical approval was obtained from the ethics committee of the University Hospital of Liege and each participant (and a close relative for AD patients) gave informed consent to participate in the study in line with the Declaration of Helsinki. The demographic characteristics of the AD and control groups are presented in Table 2.  Table 2 e Demographic characteristics of AD and control groups. Standard deviations are presented within parentheses.  Gender (F/M)  Mean age (years) Range  Years of education (mean) Range  MMSE score (mean) Range  AD group  Control group  15/10  15/10  76.16 (5.43) 63e87  10.60 (3.71) 6e17  14.36 (2.99) 10e20  74.44 (5.92) 65e86  11.96 (3.05) 6e17  28.96 (1.14) 25e30  Procedure and materials  3.1.2. 3.1.2.1. SELF-FACE RECOGNITION. This task was the same as in experiment 1 except that no reaction times were recorded. Indeed, AD patients found it difﬁcult to press buttons to provide their answers and a time pressure was likely to induce errors due to a mix-up of buttons, so oral responses were preferred. Therefore, participants responded orally at their own pace and the experimenter pressed the appropriate response button.  3.1.2.2. UNFAMILIAR FACE PROCESSING. As in experiment 1, after the face recognition task was done, unfamiliar face processing was assessed with the short form of the Benton Facial Recognition Test (Benton et al., 1983).  3.1.2.3. IMAGING PROCEDURE. Twenty out of the 25 AD patients also underwent a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) session. Two patients refused to take part in an MRI session, one patient's clinical condition (metal devices) was not compatible with MRI and two subjects were discarded because of movement artifacts. Structural and resting-state fMRI data were therefore available for 20 AD patients (13 women, mean age¼ 74.9 ± 5.4; years of education¼ 10.25 ± 4.49). The AD group in the MRI analysis did not differ from the AD cohort as a whole on measures listed in Table 3 (p > .40 for all comparisons).  All imaging data were collected on a 3-Tesla head-only Siemens Allegra scanner (Siemens, Allegra, Erlangen, Germany) with the standard transmit-receive quadrature head coil. T2*-weighted functional images were acquired using a gradient-echo planar imaging (EPI) sequence with repetition time (TR) ¼ 2040 ms, echo time (TE) ¼ 30 ms, ﬂip angle ¼ 90  , ﬁeld of view (FoV) ¼ 192  192 mm2, matrix size ¼ 64  64, voxel size ¼ 3  3  3 mm3. Thirty-four 3-mm thick transverse slices were acquired, with an interslice gap of 25%,  Table 3 e Comparison between AD group in the MRI analysis and entire AD cohort on age, years of education and three behavioral measures (% of accuracy) used in MRI analysis.  AD MRI (n ¼ 20)  All AD (n ¼ 25)  Age Years of education MMSE Self face Recent self face Familiar face  74.9 (5.4)  10.25 (4.49) 14.55 (2.91) 87.75 (23.59) 86.87 (23.46) 82.75 (31.35)  76.16 (5.43) 10.60 (3.71) 14.36 (2.99) 88.80 (21.47) 87.00 (22.09) 86.00 (28.69)  66  c o r t e x 6 7 ( 2 0 1 5 ) 5 9 e7 3  covering the whole brain. During the resting-state acquisition (250 volumes, approximately 8 min), participants were instructed to keep their eyes closed and remain awake. The ﬁrst three volumes were discarded from analyses to allow for magnetization equilibrium. Gradient-recalled sequences were applied directly after the functional sequences to acquire two complex images with different echo times (TE ¼ 4.92 and 7.38 ms respectively) and generate ﬁeld maps for distortion correction of the EPI images. A high-resolution T1-weighted image was acquired for each participant with the T1weighted 3D MPRAGE sequence with TE ¼ 4.35 ms, TR ¼ 1960 ms, TI ¼ 1100 ms, ﬁeld of view ¼ 230  173 mm2, resolution ¼ 256  192  176, voxel size ¼ .9  .9  .9 mm3. Head movement was minimized by restraining the subject's head using foam pads.  3.1.2.4. IMAGE ANALYSIS  3.1.2.4.1. PREPROCESSING. Imaging data were preprocessed and analyzed using SPM8 (Wellcome Department of Imaging Neuroscience, http//www.ﬁl.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm) implemented in MATLAB 7.12 (Mathworks Inc., Sherborn, MA). For each subject, EPI time series were corrected for motion and distortion using Realign and Unwarp (Andersson, Hutton, Ashburner, Turner, & Friston, 2001) together with the FieldMap toolbox (Hutton et al., 2002) in SPM8. Functional scans were realigned using rigid body transformations, iteratively optimized to minimize the residual sum of squares between the ﬁrst and each subsequent image separately and a mean realigned functional image was then calculated by averaging all the realigned functional scans. This mean functional image was coregistered to the structural T1-image using a rigid body transformation optimized to maximize the normalized mutual information between the two images. The resulting coregistration parameters were then applied to the realigned functional images. The mapping from subject to Montreal neurologic institute (MNI) space was estimated from the structural image using the “uniﬁed segmentation” approach (Ashburner & Friston, 2005). The warping parameters were then separately applied to the functional and structural images to produce normalized images with resolutions of 2  2  2 mm3 and 1  1  1 mm3, respectively. Finally, the warped functional images were spatially smoothed using a Gaussian kernel of 8 mm full-width at half maximum (FWHM). Artifact reduction software (ART; http://www.nitrc. org/projects/artifact_detect) was also used to account for motion artifact. Outliers in the global mean signal intensity and motion were subsequently included as nuisance parameters during the functional analysis.  3.1.2.4.2. FUNCTIONAL ANALYSES. Group functional connectivity maps in AD patients were created using the NetBrainWork toolbox (http://sites.google.com/site.netbrainwork). As implemented in the toolbox, functional networks were detected at the group level using NEDICA (Network Detection using independent component analysis (ICA); Perlbarg et al., 2008), which consists in detecting the functional networks at the individual level using spatial independent component analysis and then checking their reproducibility across subjects to provide a consistent map across subjects. In order to perform seedto-voxel analyses, regions of interest (ROIs) were chosen from  the literature on AD patients (Brier et al., 2012). These ROIs were chosen based on their involvement in the DMN and their identiﬁcation in the literature as critical regions for self- and familiar-face recognition. Two seed regions (a sphere with a radius of 8 mm around the coordinates) were selected: the dMPFC (MNI: 0, 61, 22) and the PCC (MNI: 0, e51, 29). We ensured with a visual inspection that the ROIs found in the literature overlapped with regions of the DMN map identiﬁed by NEDICA. Seed-to-voxel analyses were performed to measure the connectivity between seed regions and all brain voxels using the fMRI functional connectivity toolbox Conn (http://www.nitric. org/projects/conn). The resulting connectivity maps were entered into correlation analyses in SPM8: the independent variable was connectivity maps, and behavioral recognition scores were entered as covariate of interest. Three correlation analyses were performed with three different recognition scores: recognition of self face (independently of the life period), recognition of self face for the most recent period, and recognition of the familiar face (independently of the life period).  3.1.2.5. STATISTICAL PROCEDURES. Given that reaction times were not recorded, in this experiment, the dependent measure was only the percentage of correct responses. As in the experiment 1, we ﬁrst considered the effects of the faces' identity regardless of life period. A mixed design was used, with one betweenparticipants factor (Group, two levels: moderate-AD and control) and one within-participants factor (Identity of faces, three levels: self, familiar and unknown). Next, we considered the effects of life period for self and familiar faces. Unknown faces were excluded from this analysis because the impact of life period was irrelevant for this category of faces. A mixed design was used, with one between-participants factor (Group, two levels: moderate-AD and control) and two within-participants factors (Identity of faces, two levels: self and familiar; Age of faces, four levels: 20e30, 35e45, 50e60 and 65 and above).  Because several conditions of application of parametric ANOVAs were not respected (i.e., normality of the distribution, the homogeneity of variances and the sphericity), nonparametric analyses were carried out on the percentage of correct responses. KruskaleWallis tests and ManneWhitney tests were used for the inter-group comparisons. Friedman tests and Wilcoxon tests were used for the intra-group comparisons. Post-hoc tests were interpreted using the Bonferroni adjustment for multiple comparisons.  Finally, we examined the relationship between self-face and familiar face recognition in calculating Spearman's correlation between self-face recognition and familiar-face recognition in the AD and control groups.  3.2. Correlations To assess whether the AD group's poorer face recognition was related to dementia severity, Spearman's correlations were calculated in the AD group between self-face and familiar-face recognition performance on the one hand and MMSE scores on the other hand. None of these correlations were signiﬁcant; details are presented in Table 6.  To assess whether the AD group's poorer face recognition was related to poorer face processing, Spearman's correlations were computed between self-face and familiar-face recognition performance and the Benton facial recognition score. As shown in Table 6, self-face recognition was signiﬁcantly correlated with the Benton facial recognition score, indicating poorer self-face recognition in participants with poorer face processing. These results indicate that higher connectivity between the dMPFC and the rSFG is associated with worse recognition scores. There was no signiﬁcant correlation between recognition scores (self, recent self, relative) and the connectivity maps of the PCC seed, a region that also belongs to the DMN.  The overlap between the rSFG and the connectivity maps identiﬁed by NEDICA indicated that this region is likely to belong to the central executive network (CEN) (see Table 7 and Fig. 6).  In order to assess the speciﬁcity of the correlation to the recognition of familiar (own or relative's) faces, we examined whether general face processing abilities, as indexed by Benton facial recognition scores, were also negatively correlated with dMPFC functional connectivity, but no such negative correlation was found in our study.  3.3.  Discussion  This experiment examined self- and familiar-face recognition in the moderate stages of AD and showed a deﬁcit affecting self-face and familiar-face recognition in our sample of moderate AD patients, along with a preserved capacity to identify unknown faces. Interestingly, the AD patients' performance was highly variable and not all patients had this deﬁcit. Indeed, 52% of the AD patients (13/25) obtained a perfect score for self-face recognition, 56% (14/25) obtained a perfect score for familiar face recognition, and 40% (10/25) recognized both self and familiar faces perfectly. Moreover, as a group, the AD patients had problems with general face processing, which was correlated with poorer self-face recognition. Therefore, from a clinical viewpoint, one cannot rule out the possibility that the impairment in self- (and familiar-) face recognition may be at least partly due to impaired face processing abilities. Nevertheless, such an impairment was not conﬁrmed by the clinical and cerebral connectivity correlation. And it is noteworthy that the MMSE score was not related to performance on self- and familiarface recognition.  A second objective of the experiment was to examine the occurrence of a temporally graded loss of self-face recognition in moderate AD patients. No temporal gradient seems to occur  Table 6 e Spearman's correlations between face recognition, disease severity and face processing.  Self face Familiar face  MMSE  .28 (p ¼ .17) .15 (p ¼ .48)  Benton Facial Recognition Test  .53 (p ¼ .006) .30 (p ¼ .14)  in self-face recognition since no effect of the age of faces was observed in the AD patients. However, only 60% of AD patients achieved a perfect score for self-face recognition in recent photographs whereas 84% of them scored perfectly for selfface recognition in photographs taken at the age of 20e30. The difference between these two proportions was marginally signiﬁcant (p ¼ .058). Moreover, in comparison to healthy older adults, AD patients performed worse for recent self-face photographs, but no difference between the two groups was found for older self-face photographs. Taken together, these data suggest that self-face recognition from the recent past might possibly be more affected in AD than self-face recognition from the remote past.  Resting-state fMRI data enabled us to examine the neural correlates of the impairments detected for own- and familiarface recognition in AD, with a particular emphasis on DMN connectivity, in light of the DMN region's involvement in familiar-face recognition and the vulnerability of this network to AD pathology. The results showed a signiﬁcant negative correlation between the dMPFC and rSFG connectivity level and different familiar-face recognition scores (self, recent self and relatives). These results remained signiﬁcant when controlling for the severity of dementia (MMSE) in moderate AD. Moreover, they appear to be speciﬁc to self- and familiar-face recognition as there was no correlation with scores indexing the general ability to process faces. In other words, the results showed that the greater the connectivity between the dMPFC and rSFG, the lower the behavioral recognition scores. We hypothesized that the relationship between face recognition and DMN connectivity could take one of two forms: either higher functional connectivity within the DMN being associated with better recognition scores, or greater inter-network (DMN vs other networks) connectivity being related to worse recognition performance. In support of the former hypothesis, Damoiseaux et al. (2008) showed that in healthy older people, decreased connectivity within an anterior resting-state network was associated with cognitive decline. Furthermore, better connectivity between DMN regions has been associated with higher self-appraisal scores (Ries et al., 2012). The current ﬁndings, however, supported the latter hypothesis: poorer self- and familiar-face recognition is related to greater functional connectivity between two regions belonging respectively to the DMN and CEN.  Accordingly, increased connectivity, reﬂecting functional dedifferentiation of speciﬁc brain regions, is associated with poorer recognition scores. In other words, it could be that AD patients, in a poorly controlled attempt to compensate for difﬁculties, activate an rSFG region together with the dMPFC and, in doing so, are adopting a strategy that is deleterious to their performance. A general interpretation of these results could be that less segregation between networks in AD leads  c o r t e x 6 7 ( 2 0 1 5 ) 5 9 e7 3  69  Table 7 e Clusters in the rSFG connected to the dMPFC seed, where connectivity level is negatively correlated with recognition scores.  Coordinate (MNI) (x, y, z)  14 50 38 18 54 30 16 44 36 14 58 28 14 50 38  Cluster  size  261  151  277  Self  Recent self  Familiar  p Value corrected  With MMSE  Coordinate (MNI) (x, y, z)  Cluster size  p Value corrected  .002  .037  .002  14 50 38  16 54 34  235  525  .004  n.s.  .003  to interference between networks that are deleterious for self and familiar face processing. In the current study, it could thus be argued that, given the dMPFC's importance in selfrelated processes, information related to the self (self face or familiar faces) might be processed automatically by regions of the DMN, but the recruitment of another brain region belonging to another (executive) network involved in attentional control could affect this automatic processing. In other words, networks that are not intended to work together do so because they are less segregated as a result of AD.  Support for the idea of reduced segregation comes from recent studies (Brier et al., 2012; Wang et al., 2007) showing that AD patients demonstrate a decrease in the typical anticorrelation between resting-state networks (Fox et al., 2005). Anti-correlated networks consist of regions that normally exhibit task-related activations (e.g., the executive or frontoparietal control network) and regions that normally exhibit task-related deactivations (e.g., the DMN). Inter-network connectivity (connectivity between regions belonging to different resting state networks) is in our study characterized  by deleterious increase of correlation between regions belonging to the task positive and task negative networks.  Consistent with the reductions in these anti-correlations shown in AD patients (Brier et al., 2012; Wang et al., 2007), we propose that less segregation between the DMN and the executive network leads to interference between those networks (i.e., an increase in neural noise). This lower segregation is associated with reduced efﬁciency of the processes supported by the DMN, which in this study would correspond to recognition of self or familiar faces. In the current study, this interpretation suggests that interference in DMN functioning is associated with a decreased capacity to recognize one's own and familiar faces. Future studies should examine whether other processes related to the DMN are also disturbed by interference from other networks.  The present fMRI study has several limitations. The ﬁrst one is the choice of a priori ROIs based on the literature. Even if the method is appropriate as the ROIs come from independent data sets, it may not be the optimal procedure. A better procedure would perhaps have been to use, as seed regions,  Fig. 6 e Connectivity (red line) between the dorsomedial prefrontal seed (above) and the right superior frontal gyrus (represented in its three axes). In the right superior corner, graph of the negative correlation of the dMPFC/rSFG connectivity level and familiar face recognition scores.  70  c o r t e x 6 7 ( 2 0 1 5 ) 5 9 e7 3  areas activated during an fMRI familiar face recognition task within the target population. It is however quite challenging to carry out such tasks with AD patients. In addition, in order to demonstrate the speciﬁcity of these signiﬁcant results by choosing one particular ROI (dMPFC), we showed that correlation analyses performed with a few other regions belonging either to the DMN (PCC) or other resting-state networks, notably the salience networks (right and left insula e data not shown) or ventral visual pathway regions (fusiform gyrus and anterior ventral temporal pole e data not shown), did not provide any signiﬁcant results. A second limitation is the absence of correlation analyses in a healthy older control group. Indeed, without such a group, we cannot (and do not) claim that the result we found in our study is speciﬁc to the AD patient population in general. Another drawback is the fact that we used correlations between scores and resting-state data, thus examining an indirect link between scores and neural or cortical activation. To get around this problem, future work could examine this issue with task-related fMRI studies examining self- and familiar-face recognition. One would however need to overcome some difﬁculties. Indeed, given that, in our study, we were particularly interested in the processing of self-recognition from photographs taken at different periods of life, it would have been particularly difﬁcult for each patient to collect enough photographs representing the different periods of his/her life to meet the requirements of fMRI methodology. Furthermore, fMRI taskrelated approaches are constraining and difﬁcult to realize with AD patients, given their cognitive and behavioral difﬁculties, especially at more advanced stages of the disease.  4.  General discussion  This study revealed that impairment in self- and familiar face recognition occurred in the moderate stages of AD. However, the severity of the disease was not linearly related to face recognition performance. Moreover, there is heterogeneity among patients with AD. Indeed, one mild AD patient scored poorly for familiar face recognition. Inversely, 40% of moderate AD patients obtained a perfect score on both self and familiar face recognition task. Therefore, these ﬁndings indicated that, in the mild AD stages, impairment in self or familiar face recognition accuracy is infrequent, while they are globally slower than controls for providing answers. However, in the moderate AD stages, the probability to develop impairment in self- and familiar face recognition is increased. Such variability in face recognition performance appeared to be related to variability in cerebral functional connectivity. Furthermore, although mild AD patients had no difﬁculty with face processing in general, moderate AD patients showed impaired performance on Benton's face processing task, which was related to self-face recognition.  Our study also examined the occurrence of a temporally graded loss of self-face recognition. In mild AD patients and their healthy controls, an inverse temporal gradient was observed for RTs, with faster recognition of recent photographs than remote photographs, regardless of the identity of the faces. Two hypotheses were proposed to explain these unexpectedly result. First, faces from the remote past might  cause a “surprise” reaction that increases reaction time. In support of this, some of the participants did comment about seeing themselves or their spouses at a younger age. The second explanation is that access to self or familiar faces from the remote past might be more difﬁcult than access to such faces from the recent past; this decrease in accessibility might increase reaction times. In the moderate stages of AD, although no temporal gradient was observed, recognition of self faces from the remote past was slightly better preserved than recognition of self faces from the recent past.  The face is the most distinctive feature of our physical appearance and is critical to a sense of self (Heatherton, Macrae, & Kelley, 2004; Tsakiris, 2008). In social interactions, distinguishing between oneself and other people is essential (Van Veluw & Chance, 2014). Self-face recognition is also considered to be a cue of self-awareness (Gallup, 1982; Van Veluw & Chance, 2014). The persistence of the sense of self in AD is currently a matter of debate in the literature (Cadell & Clare, 2010). The self has been subdivided into different functionally isolable components, such as episodic memories of one's life events, semantic summary representations of one's personality traits, semantic knowledge of facts about one's life, sense of personal agency and ownership, ability to self-reﬂect, and physical self (Klein & Gangi, 2010). The present study revealed that the sense of the physical self may be impaired in moderate AD. It adds to the growing body of data demonstrating that some components of the self can be spared while others are impaired (Klein, Cosmides, & Costabile, 2003; Klein & Gangi, 2010). However, in this study, it appears that it is mainly the sense of the recent physical self that is impaired in moderate AD patients, whereas memory of the premorbid physical appearance seems to be intact.  In the behavioral study, recognition scores for self and familiar faces were highly correlated. Furthermore, with the resting-state fMRI data, we obtained the same result for each recognition score: self, recent self and relative recognition. This result may suggest that the same mechanism is operating for self- and personally familiar-face recognition in our AD patients. The ﬁnding that the same areas could be involved in both kinds of recognition is not new. Indeed, both self and personally familiar faces elicit activation in cortical midline structures (Gobbini & Haxby, 2007), which are also involved in theory of mind and mental state attribution. More speciﬁcally, the dMPFC has been implicated in a wide range of studies that require subjects to think or to infer other people's mental states (Frith & Frith, 2001; Mitchell, Banaji, & Macrae, 2005). During face recognition in healthy subjects, activity in this region has been linked to more complex forms of discrimination between the self and others (Platek & Kemp, 2009; Uddin et al., 2005). Thus, recruitment of brain areas associated with theory of mind could explain why similar mechanisms were operating and may have led to similar results for AD patients' recognition of their own faces and personally familiar faces.  Finally, our fMRI results suggest that the impaired recognition of familiar faces in moderate AD is associated with modiﬁed functional connectivity between different restingstate networks. Future studies should examine whether the modiﬁed connectivity found in our AD subjects is also present in earlier or prodromal stages of the disease (mild cognitive impairment) and healthy older controls.  c o r t e x 6 7 ( 2 0 1 5 ) 5 9 e7 3  71  Acknowledgments  This work was supported by the SAO-FRA grant S#12005, ARC 12/17-01 REST, Inter-University Attraction Pole P7/11, the F.R.S.-FNRS, and the University of Liege.  r e f e r e n c e s  Agosta, F., Pievani, M., Geroldi, C., Copetti, M., Frisoni, G. De Havas, Sarayu Parimal, Chun Siong Soon, Michael W.L. Chee ⁎ Cognitive Neuroscience Laboratory, Duke-NUS Graduate Medical School, Singapore  a r t i c l e  i n f o  a b s t r a c t  Article history: Received 17 May 2011 Accepted 9 August 2011 Available online 18 August 2011  Keywords: fMRI Sleep deprivation Default mode network Resting state Anti-correlated network Functional connectivity  Sleep deprivation (SD) can alter extrinsic, task-related fMRI signal involved in attention, memory and executive function. However, its effects on intrinsic low-frequency connectivity within the Default Mode Network (DMN) and its related anti-correlated network (ACN) have not been well characterized. We investigated the effect of SD on functional connectivity within the DMN, and on DMN-ACN anti-correlation, both during the resting state and during performance of a visual attention task (VAT). 26 healthy participants underwent fMRI twice: once after a normal night of sleep in rested wakefulness (RW) and once following approximately 24 h of total SD. A seed-based approach was used to examine pairwise correlations of lowfrequency fMRI signal across different nodes in each state. SD was associated with signiﬁcant selective reductions in DMN functional connectivity and DMN-ACN anti-correlation. This was congruent across resting state and VAT analyses, suggesting that SD induces a robust alteration in the intrinsic connectivity within and between these networks.  © 2011 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.  Introduction  A single night of total sleep deprivation (SD) can result in behavioral deﬁcits with accompanying alterations in neural activation patterns (Chee and Chuah, 2008; Goel et al., 2009). To date, the focus of most research has been on delineating the regional effects of SD on attention (Chee et al., 2008; Lim and Dinges, 2008; Tomasi et al., 2009), short-term memory (Chee and Chuah, 2007) and executive function (Nilsson et al., 2005). In contrast, far less is known about the effect of sleep deprivation on intrinsic low-frequency connectivity within the Default Mode Network (DMN) and its anti-correlated network (ACN).  The DMN is a network of brain regions that consistently deactivates in response to externally oriented tasks (Raichle et al., 2001; Shulman et al., 1997) and activates in response to numerous tasks involving internally oriented cognition (Bar, 2007; Binder et al., 2009; D'Argembeau et al., 2005; Hassabis and Maguire, 2007). The main DMN nodes—the posterior cingulate cortex (PCC), precuneus and retrosplenial cortex, the dorsal and ventral medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC), inferior parietal lobule (IPL), lateral temporal cortex (LTC), and hippocampal formation (Buckner et al., 2008)—show correlated low-frequency BOLD signal ﬂuctuations, suggesting functional connectivity (Greicius et al., 2003).  ⁎ Corresponding author at: Cognitive Neuroscience Laboratory, Duke-NUS Graduate Medical School, 8 College Road, Level 6, Singapore 169857, Singapore. Fax: +65 62218625.  E-mail address: michael.chee@duke-nus.edu.sg (M.W.L. Chee).  1053-8119/$ – see front matter © 2011 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved. doi:10.1016/j.neuroimage.2011.08.026  Interestingly, these low-frequency signals are anti-correlated with several regions normally activated as a group by externally oriented tasks (Fox et al., 2005). This anti-correlated network (ACN) includes the frontal eye ﬁelds (FEF), intraparietal sulcus (IPS), middle temporal region (MT), supplementary motor area (SMA), inferior parietal lobule (also referred to as the temporoparietal junction (TPJ; Corbetta and Shulman, 2002), dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC), and Insula (Fox et al., 2005). Switching between externally and internally oriented cognition is thought to be mediated via a competitive relationship between the ACN and DMN (Fox and Raichle, 2007; Fox et al., 2005).  Relevant to the current work, DMN connectivity and anticorrelation is diminished in many neurological and psychiatric disorders (Broyd et al., 2009; Buckner et al., 2008). Functional connectivity within the DMN is also diminished when healthy persons enter deep sleep (Horovitz et al., 2009). Both DMN functional connectivity and anti-correlation are reduced subsequent to general anesthesia (Boveroux et al., 2010; Deshpande et al., 2010), leading to the notion that diminished DMN connectivity and anti-correlation can index disrupted brain function in a variety of contexts. This motivated us to investigate if DMN connectivity and anti-correlation is altered in healthy persons undergoing a night of total SD, given the association of this state with aforementioned alterations in cognitive function.  Several SD studies evaluating short-term memory (Chee and Choo, 2004; Chee and Chuah, 2007; Choo et al., 2005) have revealed reduction in task-related deactivation across several nodes of the DMN. However, a recent study evaluating working memory reported reduced deactivation in the MPFC along with increased precuneus  1746  J.A. De Havas et al. / NeuroImage 59 (2012) 1745–1751  deactivation (Gujar et al., 2010), suggesting altered functional connectivity between DMN nodes during SD. Indeed, recent work involving partial SD reported such reductions in DMN functional connectivity, along with reduced anti-correlation between the DMN and ACN (Sämann et al., 2010).  Functional connectivity involving the DMN has typically been evaluated using resting state data, but data acquired while participants perform tasks has also been used (Fair et al., 2007; Fransson, 2006; Greicius et al., 2003; Greicius and Menon, 2004). One approach is to regress out task-related activity before evaluating DMN functional connectivity (Fair et al., 2007). Although some studies suggest that this approach generates results comparable to those obtained from resting state data (Arfanakis et al., 2000; Fair et al., 2007), others suggest otherwise (Esposito et al., 2006, 2009; Fransson, 2006).  In the present study, we evaluated the effect of SD on functional connectivity within the DMN and anti-correlation between the DMN and ACN, both during resting state and while volunteers performed a visual attention task (VAT). This comparison is important in SD studies because sleepiness increases in the supine position (Caldwell et al., 2003) and is expected to be accentuated following sleep deprivation, particularly in the absence of task performance. As such, it might be useful to assess changes in network connectivity while a person is engaged in a task to reduce the likelihood of volunteers falling asleep.  Materials and methods  Participants  Twenty-six healthy right-handed volunteers (11 male, 22.5± 2.0 years) participated in the experiment after giving informed consent. Participants were selected from respondents to a web-based questionnaire. They had to: (1) be right-handed, (2) be between 18 and 35 years of age, (3) have habitual good sleeping habits (sleeping no less than 6.5 h each night for the past one month), (4) not be of extreme morning or evening chronotype (score no greater than 22 on a modiﬁed Morningness–Eveningness scale; Horne and Ostberg, 1976), (5) not be on any long-term medications, (6) have no symptoms associated with sleep disorders, and (7) have no history of any psychiatric or neurologic disorders.  The sleeping habits of all participants were monitored throughout the two-week duration of the study, and only those whose actigraphy data indicated habitual good sleep (i.e., slept no later than 0100 h and woke no later than 0900 h) were recruited for the study.  Study procedure  Participants visited the laboratory three times. First, they attended a brieﬁng session during which they were informed about the study protocol and practiced on the experimental task. At the end of this session, every participant was given a wrist actigraph to wear throughout the study. The second and third visits involved participating in the actual fMRI experiment. The ﬁrst scanning session took place approximately one week after the initial visit. The order of the two sessions: rested wakefulness (RW) and sleep deprivation (SD), was counterbalanced across all the participants and separated by one week. This was to minimize the possibility of residual effects of sleep deprivation on cognition in participants whose sleep-deprivation session preceded their rested wakefulness session. The RW session took place at 0800 h. During the SD session, participants were monitored in the lab from 1900 h onward and scanning took place the next day at approximately 0500 h. During the SD session, participants were allowed to engage in non-strenuous activities such as reading and watching videos. Vigorous physical activity prior to the scans was not permitted. All participants indicated that they did  not smoke or consume any medications, stimulants, caffeine or alcohol for at least 24 h prior to scanning.  Experimental task  The VAT stimuli (Fig. 1) were single large, global letters (H or S; letters (H or S; 3.3° × 2.1°) composed of several, smaller local 0.6°×0.4°) (Navon, 1977). The global letter and the local letters were either congruent (i.e., a global H made up of local Hs and global S made up of local Ss) or incongruent (i.e., a global H made up of local Ss and global Ss made up of local Hs). In each trial, a single stimulus was presented centrally for 200 ms, and participants identiﬁed either the smaller, local letters or the larger, global letters by pressing one of two buttons. At the start of each run participants were told whether they would be responding to the global or local letters. For example, during a local run they were told to respond only to the local letters for the entire duration of the run. Participants performed 3 runs of the global task and 3 runs of the local task. There were 96 trials in each run, with equal numbers of congruent stimuli and incongruent stimuli. The trials were presented in a counterbalanced order that was predetermined for each participant such that there was an equal likelihood of a trial type appearing after every trial type in the design. The inter-trial interval (ITI) ranged from 3.0 to 9.0 s (mean ITI=4.2 s) following an exponential distribution that favored short ITIs. This distribution has been shown by simulation to be efﬁcient in uncovering differences in signal strength elicited by various experimental conditions (Hagberg et al., 2001).  Stimuli were presented with MR-compatible LCD goggles (Resonance Technology, Los Angeles, USA), and participants responded using a button box held in the right hand.  Fig. 1. Stimulus layout for VAT. Stimuli were single large, global letters made up of smaller local letters. Global and local letters were either congruent (i.e., a global H made up of local Hs) or incongruent (i.e., a global H made up of local Ss). During each trial, a single stimulus was presented centrally. Participants identiﬁed either the local or global letters by pressing one of two buttons.  J.A. De Havas et al. / NeuroImage 59 (2012) 1745–1751  1747  Resting state run  Following the VAT, participants completed a resting state run, during which they were instructed to lie still with their eyes focused on the central ﬁxation cross for 8 min. Participants were told to avoid head movements and swallowing.  Imaging procedure and analysis  Images were acquired on a 3T TIM Trio system (Siemens, Erlangen, Germany). A gradient echo-planar imaging sequence was used with TR of 1500 ms, ﬁeld of view of 192×192 mm and a 64×64 mm pixel matrix. Twenty-eight oblique axial slices (4 mm thick with a 0.4 mm inter-slice gap) parallel to the AC–PC line were acquired. Highresolution coplanar T1 images (0.75 × 0.75 × 4.4 mm) were also obtained to facilitate coregistration. A further high-resolution anatomical reference image was acquired using a 3D-MPRAGE sequence for the purpose of Talairach normalization.  The functional images were processed using Brain Voyager QX version 1.10.3 (Brain Innovation, Maastricht, Netherlands). To correct for motion across runs, all functional images were aligned using rigid body transformation to the ﬁrst image of the functional run acquired immediately before the coplanar T1-weighted image. Inter-slice timing differences attributable to slice acquisition order were adjusted using cubic spline interpolation. Gaussian ﬁltering was applied in the spatial domain using a smoothing kernel of 8 mm FWHM for group level analyses. The functional data was coregistered to the high-resolution anatomical image using the T1 coplanar image, before being resampled to 3 mm isovoxel resolution in Talairach space using afﬁne transformation (Talairach and Tournoux, 1988).  The main analysis involving the VAT used a single run of the task, which was truncated to have the same number of time points as the resting state analysis (318 time points). Run 3 of the VAT was selected, to minimize potential confounds such as time on task effects (Lim et al., 2010).  A band pass ﬁlter (0.009–0.09 Hz) was applied to reduce the effect of high frequency noise and very low-frequency drifts (AndrewsHanna et al., 2007; Lowe et al., 1998; Sämann et al., 2010). For each data set, a separate general linear model (GLM) analysis was then performed including the following parameters: 1) the global brain signal (including signal from ventricular CSF), and 2) the six motion correction parameters. In addition, for the VAT data, task-related activity was modeled with ﬁnite impulse response function predictors (14 timepoints, covering 21 s). The residuals were then obtained by subtracting the estimated GLM model from the time series, and used for connectivity analyses. Previous studies have found that spontaneous synchronized activity in the DMN identiﬁed after regressing out task-related activity can yield similar results to resting state data (Fair et al., 2007).  Functional connectivity was determined in the same manner for the resting state and VAT analyses. Regions of interest (ROI) were selected independently for resting state and VAT based on RW wholebrain correlation maps with an a priori deﬁned PCC seed (9×9 ×9 mm cube) taken from the literature (Andrews-Hanna et al., 2007). Despite independent selection, node locations were highly consistent across VAT and resting state analyses (Fig. 2; Suppl Tables 1 and 2).  Six additional DMN ROI whose time series showed maximum positive correlation with the PCC seed were selected: dorsal and ventral medial prefrontal cortices (dMPFC, vMPFC), bilateral inferior parietal lobules (LIPL, RIPL) and bilateral lateral temporal cortices (LLTC, RLTC).  Six ACN nodes were also selected based on voxels showing maximal anti-correlation with the PCC seed: bilateral insula (L Insula, R Insula), bilateral intraparietal sulcus (LIPS, RIPS) and bilateral temporoparietal junction (LTPJ, RTPJ). These speciﬁc nodes were chosen based on reports that they belong to putative sub-networks of  the ACN: the insula is implicated in a salience network (Seeley et al., 2007; Sridharan et al., 2008); the IPS in the dorsal attention network; and the TPJ in the ventral attention network (Corbetta and Shulman, 2002; Fox et al., 2006a).  For RW and SD, functional connectivity during resting state and VAT analyses was assessed by computing pairwise correlations across the 7 DMN nodes and between the 7 DMN nodes and 6 ACN nodes (time series averaged across a cube of size 9 ×9×9 mm). The r values were Fisher-transformed (z’) before further parametric statistical analyses to ensure that the data approximated a normal distribution. To determine the effect of SD on functional connectivity and anticorrelation, 2×2 repeated measures ANOVA were performed on the z′ values obtained from each node pairing (data type; resting state vs. VAT×state; RW vs. SD). All statistics were Bonferroni corrected for multiple comparisons.  An additional analysis to investigate functional connectivity changes within the DMN across state was carried out using all 6 runs of the VAT. Here, preprocessing and analysis was the same as the above VAT analysis. However, the 6 DMN ROI were picked independently for each run. Pearson's r values for each of the node pairings in RW and SD were then averaged across the 6 runs. These averaged r values were then Fisher-transformed, before two-tailed, repeated measures t-tests between RW and SD (Bonferroni corrected) were performed on the z’ values obtained from each node pairing.  Behavioral analysis  Response time was determined using only trials with correct responses (correct RT), excluding lapse trials (no response or RT N3000 ms). The intra-individual coefﬁcient of variation was calculated for each participant by dividing the standard deviation of correct RT by the mean correct RT. This value was then averaged across participants for each state.  Behavioral accuracy was measured using corrected recognition (Hits–False Alarms). Behavioral deﬁcits related to SD were evaluated using paired one-tailed t-tests. SD-related functional connectivity reduction and SD-related declines in behavioral performance were then correlated to examine the functional consequences of changes in DMN connectivity and behavior.  Results  Behavioral ﬁndings  Sleep deprivation resulted in a decline in response accuracy (RW mean accuracy 89.4%, SD mean accuracy 77.8%; t25=5.15, p b0.0001; Table 1). The number of behavioral lapses increased during SD relative to RW (12.5% vs. 2.8%; t25 =5.65, p b0.0001). SD resulted in slower responses (RTcorrect 687 ms vs. RTcorrect 632 ms; t25 =3.38, p b0.01) and increased intra-individual variability in response time (0.29 vs. 0.22; t25 =4.78, p b0.0001).  Reduced functional connectivity within DMN nodes: observed in both VAT and resting state analyses  Within the DMN, there was a main effect of state on the functional connectivity of 3 node pairs: dMPFC and LIPL; vMPFC and LIPL; PCC and LIPL (Fig. 3; Suppl. Table 3).  Reduced anti-correlation between DMN and ACN nodes: observed in both VAT and resting state analyses  A main effect of state was found on the anti-correlation between 20 DMN-ACN node pairs. The effect was mostly present between lateral nodes of the DMN, particularly IPL, and much of the ACN (Fig. 4; Suppl. Table 4).  1748  J.A. De Havas et al. / NeuroImage 59 (2012) 1745–1751  Fig. 2. DMN and ACN node location in Rest and VAT. Correlation maps between an a priori selected PCC seed (9× 9×9 mm cube) and all other voxels in the brain. All other nodes were selected based on the r values (9 ×9×9 mm cube centered on peak voxel), 6 from the DMN (positive r, yellow labels), and 6 from the ACN (negative r, blue labels). The nodes were deﬁned separately for the resting state and VAT data, but show a high degree of spatial overlap (Suppl. Tables 1 and 2). Black squares depict actual voxels selected for each node.  Effects of data type or interaction between data type and state  Discussion  Within the DMN, no signiﬁcant effects of data type, or interactions between data type and state, were found (Suppl. Table 3). Between the DMN and ACN, a single signiﬁcant data type by state interaction was found between LLTC and LTPJ (F1,25=21.00, p b0.001).  The effect of utilizing additional VAT runs  Analysis was also conducted using the average of all 6 VAT runs. Within the DMN, 14 node pairings showed a signiﬁcant negative effect of SD on functional connectivity (Fig. 5).  We found SD to be associated with reduced functional connectivity within the DMN and reduced anti-correlation between the DMN and ACN. This was true for both resting state and VAT analyses. Declines in DMN connectivity and anti-correlation consistently affected the IPL nodes. Despite inherent differences between resting state and VAT time series, there was no signiﬁcant effect of data type or interaction between data type and state when comparing data of equivalent duration. However, analyzing the data using multiple VAT runs uncovered more extensive declines in DMN functional connectivity. Finally, despite the unequivocal state changes in connectivity and  Absence of brain-behavior correlation  The observed decline (RW-SD) in functional connectivity between 3 DMN node pairings during the resting state did not signiﬁcantly correlate with any of the behavioral measures derived from the VAT (RW-SD; corrected accuracy, RTcorrected, RT variability and behavioral lapses; Suppl. Table 5). This was also true of the decline in functional connectivity within the DMN during VAT (Suppl. Table 6) and of the SD-related reduced anti-correlation, both during resting state and VAT (Suppl. Tables 5 and 6). A signiﬁcant main effect of state on DMN functional connectivity was found between 3 node pairs; LIPL and dMPFC, LIPL and vMPFC, and LIPL and PCC (Bonferroni corrected p b0.05/21 =0.002).  J.A. De Havas et al. / NeuroImage 59 (2012) 1745–1751  1749  also been demonstrated after Propofol-induced loss of consciousness (Boveroux et al., 2010). Moreover, these within and between network decouplings appear to be graded, with deeper anesthesia being associated with more widespread losses of connectivity (Boveroux et al., 2010; Deshpande et al., 2010).  We found that SD-related alterations in connectivity and anticorrelation most consistently involved the IPL nodes. Previous work has found SD-related reduced IPL deactivation during a visual shortterm memory task (Chee and Chuah, 2007), while resting state analysis has revealed reductions in IPL-MPFC functional connectivity during sleep (Horovitz et al., 2009) and after partial SD (Sämann et al., 2010). The IPL region is implicated in diverse cognitive operations (Laird et al., 2009), including bodily awareness (Felician et al., 2009), generating a sense of personal responsibility (Schaich Borg et al., 2006), and moral decision-making (Raine and Yang, 2006). These functions correspond to behaviors negatively affected by SD. Bodily connection (Giesbrecht et al., 2007), blame acceptance (Kahn-Greene et al., 2006), and responding to personal moral dilemmas (Killgore et al., 2007) are all impaired following SD. Further work is needed to explore whether this cluster of deﬁcits maps onto SD-related reduced IPL functional connectivity and anti-correlation.  Fig. 4. Main effect of state on DMN-ACN anti-correlation. A signiﬁcant main effect of state on anti-correlation was found between 20 DMN-ACN node pairs (Bonferroni corrected p b0.05/42 =0.001).  anti-correlation, there was no signiﬁcant correlation between these alterations and behavioral changes induced by sleep deprivation.  Task data compliments resting state  SD is associated with reductions in DMN functional connectivity and anti-correlation  Reduced responsiveness to the environment is associated with declines in functional connectivity within and between brain networks. Reduced functional connectivity between anterior and posterior midline nodes of the DMN was observed during the transition into slow-wave sleep (Horovitz et al., 2009; Sämann et al., 2011). Slow-wave sleep has also been associated with reduced anti-correlation between the DMN and nodes of the ACN, such as the insula (Sämann et al., 2011). Such ﬁndings are not limited to deep sleep. They have been demonstrated during light sleep (Sämann et al., 2011) and after partial sleep deprivation (Sämann et al., 2010). Indeed, when responsiveness to the external environment is pharmacologically suppressed, connectivity between the PCC and other DMN nodes was similarly reduced (Greicius et al., 2008). Reduced anti-correlation between the DMN and parts of the ACN has  Fig. 5. Effect of state on DMN functional connectivity: average of 6 VAT runs. An analysis using an average of 6 VAT runs found extensive functional connectivity declines within the DMN after SD. t-tests showed signiﬁcant effects of SD in 14 of 21 node pairings (RW NSD, Bonferroni corrected p b0.05/21 =0.002).  We explored whether the effects of SD on the DMN and ACN would be detectable in the underlying BOLD signal after regressing out taskrelated activity. As we sought to reduce the effect of sleep intrusions on the data, we originally anticipated this data type to be less sensitive to connectivity alterations than the resting state data. This is because performance of the VAT ensured participants maintained a higher degree of wakefulness. However, we found only a single signiﬁcant interaction between data type and state, and no main effects of data type, both within the DMN, and between the DMN and ACN.  While in broad agreement with previous work comparing resting state connectivity inferred from task-related and resting state data (Fair et al., 2007), these present results differ from ICA-based studies. These latter studies have reported changes in the spatial extent of functional connectivity within the DMN with increased working memory load relative to resting state data (Esposito et al., 2006, 2009). The absence of such changes in the current study may stem from a difference in the measure of interest. Rather than focus on spatial extent, the seed-based approach used here compared correlations between spatially bounded nodes.  We found reduced DMN functional connectivity and anti-correlation during the VAT. This ﬁnding concurs with studies showing SD-related reduced DMN deactivation during task performance (Chee and Choo, 2004; Chee and Chuah, 2007; Choo et al., 2005). Intrinsic low-frequency activity has been postulated to inﬂuence activity at higher-frequency bands via power modulations (Buzsáki and Draguhn, 2004; Leopold et al., 2003). In support of this, intrinsic activity in motor regions has been shown to account for a signiﬁcant proportion of the inter-trial variability in activity evoked by a button press task (Fox et al., 2006b), and for variance in behavioural performance (Fox et al., 2007). Thus, altered low-frequency functional connectivity within the DMN, and between the DMN and ACN, could contribute to impaired task-related DMN deactivation after SD.  Potential beneﬁts of using multi-run task data to assess DMN connectivity  We found that using multiple VAT runs uncovered more extensive alteration in DMN functional connectivity after SD. Research on underlying correlations in low-frequency activity in the DMN and ACN often involves only resting state data, because it is straightforward to acquire, and “uncontaminated” by task activity (Fransson, 2006). Comparisons across groups or states are thus typically based on a single run of 6–10 min. Acquiring more resting state data to increase  1750  J.A. De Havas et al. / NeuroImage 59 (2012) 1745–1751  the power to detect subtle alterations between groups may decrease the signal to noise ratio due to factors such as increased head motion (Fox and Greicius, 2010). Additionally, it might be difﬁcult to elicit the co-operation of volunteers with behavioral abnormalities, young children or those who are disposed to falling asleep. Using task data may circumvent some of these issues. Multiple runs are already collected, allowing an analysis based on markedly more data points. Critically, the present study demonstrates that task data can be used to show both equivalent results to resting state when the volume of data is matched, and more extensive effects when multiple task runs are used.  Absence of brain-behavior correlations  Despite unequivocal SD-related behavioral declines in VAT performance and reductions in both DMN functional connectivity and DMN-ACN anti-correlation, no signiﬁcant correlations were found between these measures at the level of individual subjects. This was unexpected, given that stop-signal errors (Li et al., 2007) and lapses of attention (Weissman et al., 2006) have been associated with a failure to deactivate the DMN. However, little is known about how intrinsic activity interacts with task-related activity, and by extension, behavioral performance (Northoff et al., 2010). Furthermore, the few studies that do report correlations between resting functional connectivity and behavioral measures (e.g. Kelly et al., 2008) have tended to use attention-demanding tasks such as the Eriksen ﬂanker task. Delineating the intrinsic network properties that correlate with less demanding tasks such as the VAT may require a ﬁne-grained approach that goes beyond examining limited DMN and ACN nodes.  Limitations  Analysis was restricted to bivariate correlations between node pairs. Consequently, only relative changes between nodes could be detected. It was not possible to determine how SD affected individual nodes, or how the nodes inﬂuenced one another across states. Techniques such as ICA and Granger causality analysis could be used in the future to explore these questions. Further, the results of our task analysis were based on a single VAT. As such, they apply primarily to visual attention and cannot be generalized to other behavioural domains.  Conclusion  SD was associated with reduced DMN functional connectivity and DMN-ACN anti-correlation. This was true in the resting state and VAT analyses. The IPL node of the DMN was consistently impaired and may represent an early marker for the effects of SD, as well as an indicator of hitherto unexplored behavioural impairments. We demonstrated that task data could be used to show equivalent results to resting state when the volume of data was matched, supporting the notion that reduced deactivation after SD may be related to intrinsic DMN impairment. Moreover, we found more extensive effects of SD when multiple task runs were used, implying that under certain conditions task data may be preferable. How functional connectivity relates to behaviour and stimulus-evoked activation and deactivation of the DMN and ACN remains to be elucidated. SD is a useful assay for such questions since it represents one of the few reversible state changes that allows participants to perform relatively demanding tasks. Neurosci. 9, 971–978.  www.elsevier.com/locate/ynimg NeuroImage 41 (2008) 1447 – 1461  Social cognitive neural networks during in-group and out-group interactions James K. Rilling,a,b,c,d,⁎ Julien E. Dagenais,a David R. Goldsmith,a Andrea L. Glenn,a and Giuseppe Pagnonib  aDepartment of Anthropology, Emory University, 1557 Dickey Drive, Atlanta, GA 30322, USA bDepartment of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Emory University, 1639 Pierce Drive, Atlanta, GA 30322, USA cCenter for Behavioral Neuroscience, USA dYerkes National Primate Research Center, Emory University, USA  Received 19 September 2007; revised 13 March 2008; accepted 26 March 2008 Available online 7 April 2008  Several functionally connected networks of activity have now been identified in the resting human brain that may be amplified or attenuated by specific goal-directed tasks. However, it is not known whether there exists a particular network that becomes more active when a person is engaged in a social interaction. fMRI was used to measure brain activity in subjects as they completed a social interactive task and a non-social control task sharing many of the same features. Comparison across the two tasks revealed a network of functionally connected areas that was consistently more active in the social task. This network included default mode network areas, raising the possibility that activity previously observed in default mode regions at rest is related to social cognition. Within this network, information appears to flow from regions involved in salience detection (e.g. anterior insula) to regions involved in mentalizing (dorsomedial prefrontal cortex) to regions involved in executive control (dorsolateral prefrontal cortex). In a second experiment, subjects played the same social interactive task with alleged members of both an experimentally induced in-group and out-group. The default mode network was again active during the task, and several noteworthy differences distinguished interactions with in-group and out-group partners, providing a potential neural substrate for the human tendency to more readily identify with in-group members and more readily distrust, fear and discriminate against out-group members. © 2008 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.  ⁎ Corresponding author. Department of Anthropology, Emory University, 1557 Dickey Drive, Atlanta, GA 30322, USA. Fax: +1 404 727 2860.  E-mail address: jrillin@emory.edu (J.K. Rilling). URL:  http://www.anthropology.emory.edu/FACULTY/ANTJR/labhome1.html (J.K. Rilling).  Available online on ScienceDirect (www.sciencedirect.com).  1053-8119/$ - see front matter © 2008 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved. doi:10.1016/j.neuroimage.2008.03.044  Introduction  Recently, there has been a movement in cognitive neuroscience towards identifying functional networks of brain activity, as an adjunct to the standard approach of identifying maximal activations in specific brain regions. As many as 10 such networks have been identified in the resting state (Damoiseaux et al., 2006), including networks hypothesized to be involved in vision, sensorimotor processing, auditory processing, language, memory, executive control, emotional salience and self-referential processing (Beckmann et al., 2005; Biswal et al., 1995; Cordes et al., 2000; Fox et al., 2005; Fransson, 2005; Greicius et al., 2003; Lowe et al., 1998; Seeley et al., 2007). Activity in some of these networks is modulated as subjects transition from a resting state to goaldirected task engagement. As expected, some networks are amplified by tasks that engage their putative functions (De Luca et al., 2005; Fransson, 2005; Hampson et al., 2004, 2002). However, the default mode network is apparently attenuated by a wide range of goal-directed tasks, suggesting that it may be involved in resting state cognitive processes that are disrupted during goal-directed task engagement.  An important question for social neuroscience is whether a particular neural network becomes more active when a person is engaged in a social, interactive task compared to a non-social, goal-directed task. There is reason to think that the default mode network may behave in this way. The default mode network is hypothesized to relate to self-referential mental activity (Gusnard et al., 2001). However, according to simulation theory, we understand others' mental states by imagining our own thoughts, feelings or behaviors in a similar situation (Adolphs, 2002; Davies and Stone, 1995; Gallese and Goldman, 1998; Gordon, 1992; Iacoboni et al., 2005; Meltzoff and Brooks, 2001). Therefore, the default mode network may be involved in understanding other's mental states by way of simulation  1448  J.K. Rilling et al. / NeuroImage 41 (2008) 1447–1461  combined with mental self-reflection. Consistent with this hypothesis is considerable evidence suggesting that this network, or components of it, is involved in thinking about the mental states of others (Amodio and Frith, 2006; Buckner and Carroll, 2007; Gallagher and Frith, 2003; Mitchell et al., 2002, 2006; Rilling et al., 2004). We therefore hypothesized that the default mode network would be more active during a social task that elicited mental perspective taking than during a non-social task. Experiment 1 was designed to test this hypothesis.  Experiment 2 was designed to evaluate whether any functional networks that are active during social interaction are modulated by the group identity of the playing partner, that is, whether the partner belongs to the subject's in-group or outgroup. There is abundant evidence from social psychology that people tend to more readily identify with in-group members and more readily distrust, fear and discriminate against out-group members (Hewstone et al., 2002). Early experiments showed that in-group, out-group biases could be elicited with surprising ease, even in the absence of conflicts of interest or a history of hostility between group members. Simply dividing subjects into groups on the basis of painting preferences or judgments of the number of dots in a cluster were sufficient to elicit these biases. These results were interpreted to suggest that group membership is internalized as a social is enhanced by distinguishing positively the in-group from the out-group (Tajfel and Turner, 1979). However, subsequent work established that discrimination in this minimal group paradigm (MGP), at least among male subjects, requires that subjects' payoffs are dependent on the actions of other in-group members. Thus, among males, discrimination in the MGP is thought to depend on a norm of reciprocity with in-group members (Gaertner and Insko, 2000).  identity that  Previous neuroimaging studies have investigated the neural correlates of social perception of in-group and out-group members, in which group status was racially defined (Eberhardt, 2005). These studies have focused on responses in the amygdala because of its role in processing threatening stimuli. Hart et al. (2000) demonstrated faster amygdala habituation to in-group compared with out-group faces and Phelps et al. (2000) showed that White subjects with the most negative implicit attitudes towards Blacks showed the largest differential amygdala response to Black as compared with White faces. Yet, amygdala responses to racial out-group faces are not inevitable. Wheeler and Fiske showed that amygdala activation to Black faces was only found when subjects were motivated to socially categorizing those faces (Wheeler and Fiske, 2005), and a study by Cunningham et al. (2004) suggested that White subjects could use prefrontal cortex to consciously regulate racial biases and dampen amygdala activation to Black faces. Nevertheless, these studies and to our knowledge all previous neuroimaging studies have only examined in-group–out-group effects on social perception, and not during dynamic social interaction. In this study, we used a minimal group paradigm to test for potential differences in functional connectivity during in-group and outgroup interactions. We experimentally induced in-group and outgroup status in each of two playing partners (see Materials and methods) and compared subjects' brain activity as they allegedly interacted with each. In actuality, to control for the behavior of the two playing partners, in-group and out-group partner choices were administered by the same pre-programmed computer algorithm (see Materials and methods).  Materials and methods  Experiment 1  Subjects  Twenty participants from the Emory University community were studied. Mean age was 20.8years (SD = 1.6). One motivation for this study was to compare results with a previous study that focused exclusively on female subjects (Rilling et al., 2002). To facilitate this comparison and improve statistical power, the present study was also restricted to females.  Behavioral procedures  Our social task is the Prisoner's Dilemma (PD) Game, in which two players choose whether or not to cooperate with one another and receive a financial payoff that depends on the interaction of their two, independent choices. The payoff matrix in Fig. 1 specifies four possible outcomes of a round and their associated payoffs for both players: player A and player B cooperate (CC), player A cooperates and player B defects (CD), player A defects and player B cooperates (DC), or player A and player B defect (DD). The payoffs for the various outcomes are arranged such that DC N CC N DD N CD and CC N (CD + DC) / 2. Thus, choosing to cooperate is risky, because although it will yield a $2 payoff when the partner also cooperates, it will yield $0 if the partner defects. On the other hand, the lowest payoff for defecting is $1 (when the partner also defects).  Our non-social control task attempts to control for the frequency and amount of monetary payoffs, as well as non-social risk-taking behavior, and the proportion of risky choices that are rewarded. Subjects were asked to choose between a small but certain reward (100% chance of receiving $1) and a larger ($2) but uncertain reward, while being told only that the probability of the $2 reward was non-zero and that it fluctuated from trial to trial. In actuality, the probability was matched to the probability that cooperation was reciprocated in our earlier iterated PD study (77%) (Rilling et al., 2002). Thus, in both the PD and the Gamble tasks, subjects likely use past outcomes to calculate the wisdom of opting for a riskier, but potentially more rewarding outcome. However, PD game outcomes are dependent on the interaction of two autonomous agents, and in the PD game, subjects are likely additionally calculating how their current choices will affect the partner's future choices. Thus, the PD game is more complex than the gamble task. However, we believe this complexity results in large part from the fact that the task is social. In other words, part of what makes social tasks different from other tasks is their inherent complexity.  Subjects completed a 10-minute computer tutorial  that explained the Prisoner's Dilemma game, and were given a 2question multiple choice quiz to evaluate their understanding. If either question was answered incorrectly, study personnel explained to participants why that answer was wrong and why another answer was correct. If necessary, subjects repeated the tutorial. Study personnel continued with the experiment only after they were convinced that the subject fully comprehended the task. Subjects then completed two practice rounds of the PD game, as well as two practice rounds of the Gamble task using the response box they would be holding while in the scanner. The practice trials familiarized subjects with the feel of the game and the operation of the response box. Just prior to entering the scanner, subjects were introduced to two female confederates with whom  J.K. Rilling et al. / NeuroImage 41 (2008) 1447–1461  1449  fMRI image acquisition  Subjects lay motionless in a supine position in the scanner. Functional images were acquired on a Siemens 3T Trio scanner using an EPI sequence with the following parameters: TR = 2000 ms, TE = 25 ms, matrix = 64 × 64, FOV = 192mm, slice thickness = 3 mm, gap = 1 mm, 32 axial slices. The duration of each of the two EPI scans was 22min. These were followed by a 7min T1-weighted MPRAGE scan (TR = 2300 ms, TE = 4 ms, matrix = 256 × 256, slice thickness = 1.33 mm, gap = 0 mm).  fMRI image analysis  Image pre-processing was conducted using Brain Voyager QX (version 1.3.8) software (Brain Innovation, Maastricht, The Netherlands). Pre-processing involved image realignment using 6-parameter 3-D motion correction, slice scan time correction using linear interpolation, intensity normalization to the global mean of each image, spatial smoothing with a 10 mm FWHM Gaussian kernel, and temporal smoothing using voxel-wise linear detrending and high pass filtering of frequencies below three cycles per run length. Images were subsequently normalized into Talairach space (Talairach and Tournoux, 1988). A separate general linear model (GLM) was defined for each subject that examined the neural response to PD game trials and Gamble trials. We defined two regressors: one spanning the entire length of each PD trial and another spanning the entire length of each Gamble trial. Each regressor was convolved with a standardized model of the hemodynamic response. The resulting general linear model was corrected for temporal autocorrelation using a first-order autoregressive model. For each subject, contrasts of parameter estimates between PD and Gamble trials were computed at every voxel of the brain. One-sample t-tests were used to identify voxels where the average contrast (PD–Gamble) for the whole group (n = 20 subjects) differed significantly from zero (i.e., a random effect analysis). The resulting map of the t statistic was thresholded at p b 0.005, with a spatial extent threshold of 5 contiguous voxels.  Functional connectivity analysis  The dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (DMPFC) activation from the PD–Gamble contrast was defined as an ROI. The ROI was centered on the voxel of peak activity within DMPFC and included all activated voxels within 25 mm in the x, y and z directions. The time course within this ROI was extracted and standardized by removing the mean and normalizing by the standard deviation for each PD trial. Because the run consisted of Gamble trials interspersed with PD trials, PD time courses had to be isolated and spliced together to form a single non-interrupted time course that consisted of only PD trials. To accomplish this, we modeled the HRF response to PD trials and included only those volumes where the modeled HRF response was maximal. Whole brain EPI data were treated similarly, isolating and splicing together scans from PD trials. These spliced data were used for a new GLM in which the PD time course from the DMPFC ROI was included as the lone  Fig. 1. Payoff matrix used in PD game. Scanned player's choices are atop columns and non-scanned partner's choices are beside rows. Payoff to scanned player is in bold. Payoff to non-scanned partner is in parentheses.  they were told they would play the PD game. Subjects participated in two scanning runs. Each run consisted of 20 rounds of a simultaneous-choice, iterated Prisoner's Dilemma game randomly intermixed with 20 rounds of the Gamble task. Subjects were prepared to anticipate either PD or Gamble trials on each round of the game.  real human subjects (n = 19)  While in the scanner but prior to beginning each scanning run, subjects were shown a photograph of their alleged partner for the PD game in that run (actually a confederate). Subjects were told that they would play the game with their human partners, but in actuality they played against a computer strategy that was based on behavior of from our previous experiments (Rilling et al., 2002). That is, behavioral data from human subjects who played outside the scanner in a previous experiment were used to calculate the probability that a person would cooperate, as a function of the outcome of the previous two rounds of the game. A separate set of probabilities was calculated for the first and last 10 rounds, and the computer algorithm played according to these probabilities.  A timeline for a single trial is depicted in Fig. 2. On PD trials, the round number was displayed for 3s, after which subjects were shown a payoff matrix and had 6s to choose to cooperate or defect by pressing a button, which would highlight the column corresponding to their choice. This was followed 9s of a fixation cross before the partner's choice (i.e. trial outcome) was revealed and displayed for 6s. An additional 9s fixation separated the outcome from the next round.  Gamble trials began by displaying the round number for 3s. Afterwards, subjects were instructed to press one button to choose the $1 payoff or a different button to choose the risky option. They had 6s to make this choice. This was followed by 9s of a fixation cross, after which the payoff for that round was revealed and displayed for 6s. An additional 9s fixation separated the outcome from the next round. E-prime software (Psychology Software Tools, Pittsburgh) was used for stimulus presentation. Stimuli were projected onto a screen that subjects could view through a mirror mounted on the head coil. Subject responses were recorded using a response box. Each of the two runs lasted 22min.  Fig. 2. Timeline of PD trials for both Experiment 1 and Experiment 2.  1450  J.K. Rilling et al. / NeuroImage 41 (2008) 1447–1461  regressor. This GLM identified voxels in which the time course of activation during the PD trials covaried with that of DMPFC. For each subject, beta values for this regressor were calculated on a voxel-by-voxel basis across the brain. One-sample t-tests were used to identify voxels where the average beta value for the whole group (n = 20 subjects) differed significantly from zero (i.e., a random effects analysis).The resulting map of the t statistic was thresholded at t N 7.0 (p b 10− 6), with a spatial extent threshold of 5 contiguous voxels. For comparison, a similar map of DMPFC connectivity was calculated for Gamble trials.  Granger causality analysis  The DMPFC ROI from the PD–Gamble contrast was selected as a reference region to map sources of influence to DMPFC and targets of influence from DMPFC across the brain. As defined by Granger Causality theory, a discrete time series X[t] is said to “Granger-cause” a discrete time series Y[t] if the past values of X improve the prediction of the current value of Y, given that all other sources of influence (at the very least Y's own past) have been taken into account (Roebroeck et al., 2005). Temporal information in the data is thus used to define the existence and direction of influence without the need to establish a model of assumed regional connectivity. The GCM plugin offered by Brain Voyager allows one to visualize difference causality maps, in which positive values indicate where influence from the reference region dominates and negative values indicate where influence to the reference region dominates.  The Granger Causality analysis was first conducted at the individual level to generate a t statistic image of the difference Granger Causality Map for each subject. For each individual granger map, bootstrapped p-values were subjected to an FDR-based correction at a q-level of 0.01 in order to correct for multiple comparisons. Individual maps are provided in Supplementary Fig. 1. A group level analysis was then conducted by comparing the average of the individual t statistic maps with 0 using a one sample t statistic. The resulting group t statistic image was thresholded at p b 0.05, uncorrected for multiple comparisons (Fig. 5). A Granger analysis was conducted separately for PD and Gamble trials.  Experiment 2  Subjects  Thirty participants (15 females) from the Emory University  community were studied. Mean age was 21.2years (SD = 2.9).  Behavioral procedures  Prior to the day of the fMRI scan, subjects were asked to take a bogus personality test. The test included questions in which subjects were asked to estimate the frequency of various events (e.g., How many people travel through the Atlanta airport each day?). Whether or not answers to these questions are actually affected by personality is irrelevant to the experiment, as are the actual answers provided by subjects. When subjects arrived on the day of the experiment, they were assigned to either the red group or the black group, allegedly based on the answers they gave on the test, and were asked to wear a wristband of the respective color. In actuality, group assignment was determined by the order in which subjects were scanned, with the sequence alternating between red group and black group. Prior to entering the scanner, subjects met two confederates, one of whom was wearing a wristband of the same color and another who was wearing a wristband of a different color.
