Although we included both male and female subjects, confederates were always of the same sex as the subject. It was not logistically possible to use the same two confederates for each scan, however all confederates were either undergraduate or graduate students from a similar age range (18–30years). Confederates were not necessarily of the same race as the subject. Subjects were told that their partners had also completed the personality survey and were classified as belonging to the red or black group based on their responses. Subjects were told that they would play 20 rounds of an iterated PD game with each of the two partners. The meeting between subjects and their partners consisted of a very brief introduction in which the two parties could greet one another but were not given the opportunity to engage in conversation.  As for Experiment 1, before meeting the confederates, all subjects completed a tutorial, quiz and practice trials. Finally, subjects were shown a chart depicting cumulative earnings of three fictitious subject pairs, one in which both individuals were from the red group, one in which both individuals were from the black group, and one in which one individual was from the red group and another from the black group. Subjects were told that no subject pair had yet earned the maximum amount possible. Given that group affiliation is often strongest in contexts involving competition between groups, this manipulation was included as an attempt to further differentiate feelings toward in-group and out-group partners.  J.K. Rilling et al. / NeuroImage 41 (2008) 1447–1461  1451  While being imaged with fMRI, subjects played twenty rounds of an iterated Prisoner's Dilemma Game in each of two sessions. The subject played with the in-group partner in one session and with the out-group partner in the other session. Prior to the start of each game, the visual display inside the scanner indicated with which partner the subject was about to play the game, as well as the group status of that partner (i.e., red group or black group). The order in which subjects faced in-group and out-group partners was counterbalanced across subjects. Subjects were told that they were playing with each of the two human partners they had met previously. However, in actuality, partner choices were administered by a computer algorithm that played a “forgiving tit for tat” strategy that defects in round 1, always reciprocates partner cooperation from the previous round, and reciprocates partner defection from the previous round 67% of the time. This forgiving aspect of the strategy helps to prevent long runs of mutual defection (Axelrod, 1984). Each trial began by showing the name of the partner and their group affiliation for 3s. Subjects were then shown a payoff matrix and had 6s to choose to cooperate or defect, which would highlight the column corresponding to their choice. Afterwards, subjects viewed a fixation cross for 9s before the partner's choice (i.e. trial outcome) was revealed and displayed for 6s. An additional 9s fixation separated the outcome from the next round. Each of the two runs lasted 11min.  At the end of the experiment, each subject was asked whether or not they felt different when interacting with the in-group vs. the out-group partner. The 12 subjects who answered in the affirmative were classified as “discriminators” for subsequent analyses, whereas the 18 who indicated that they did not feel different were classified as “non-discriminators”. Demographic characteristics of each subject are provided in Table 1. Male and female subjects were quite evenly distributed across discriminators and non-discriminators. The 12 discriminators included 5 females and 7 males, and the 18 non-discriminators included 10 females and 8 males.  fMRI image acquisition  Subjects lay motionless in a supine position in the scanner. Functional images were acquired on a Siemens 3T Trio scanner using an EPI sequence with the following parameters: TR = 2000 ms, TE = 22 ms, matrix = 64 × 64, FOV = 192 mm, slice thickness = 3 mm, gap = 1 mm, 32 axial slices. The duration of each of the two  Table 2 Activations for contrast PD–Gamble in Experiment 1  Brain region  EPI scans was 11min. These were followed by a 7min T1-weighted MPRAGE scan (TR = 2300 ms, TE = 4 ms, matrix = 256 × 256, slice thickness = 1.33 mm, gap = 0 mm).  fMRI image analysis  A separate general linear model (GLM) was defined for each subject that examined the neural response to in-group and outgroup runs in the PD game. We defined two regressors for each subject: one spanning the entire length of the run with the in-group partner and another spanning the entire length of the run with the out-group partner. Importantly, intensity values for each voxel of an image were normalized to the global mean for that image, so that regional activation relative to the global mean could be compared across sessions with in-group and out-group partners.  ROI analysis. For each of the putative theory-of-mind related activations from the PD–Gamble contrast in Experiment 1, an ROI was centered on the activation peak and included all activated voxels within 25 mm in the x, y and z directions. Within each of these ROIs, activation during the in-group run was contrasted with activation during the out-group run using the GLM specified above. Given that previous studies have reported differential activation in the amygdala and DLPFC when evaluating faces from racial in-groups vs. out-groups (Eberhardt, 2005), we additionally defined ROIs in these two structures. The DLPFC ROI was a 9 mm radius sphere centered on the peak activation coordinate reported in (Cunningham et al., 2004) for the contrast between viewing Black and White faces, and the amygdala ROI was drawn on one subject's Talairach transformed anatomical scan, with the aid of a reference atlas (Duvernoy, 1999).  To identify brain regions where connectivity with DMPFC was stronger for in-group than out-group partners, the time course within the DMPFC ROI from Experiment 1 was extracted and standardized by removing the mean and normalizing by the standard deviation for all in-group and out-group runs. In a new GLM, these in-group and out-group time courses were included as regressors and the contrast between them identified brain voxels with stronger DMPFC connectivity for in-group vs. out-group runs. For each subject, contrast values were calculated on a voxelby-voxel basis across the brain. Whole brain exploratory analysis. The resulting map of the r statistic was thresholded at r N 0.58 (p b 0.001), with a 5 voxel spatial extent threshold.  Emotion ratings  After each of the two games were completed while still in the scanner, subjects rated their emotional reaction to the four PD game outcomes (CC, CD, DC, DD) using the button box. For Experiment 1, seven point Likert scales were used to rate the following emotions/feelings: angry, happy, irritated, guilty, camaraderie, trust, disappointment, and relieved. For Experiment 2, a larger number of emotions/feelings were rated: afraid, envious, angry, sad, happy, ashamed, irritated, contemptuous, jealous, guilty, camaraderie, trust, betrayed, indignant, disappointed, and relieved.  which time they were given the option to have their data deleted if they wished. None of our subjects chose to do so.  Results  Behavioral results  The difference in the number of times a subject cooperated with the in-group compared with the out-group partner (cooperation difference score) was calculated for each subject (Table 1). For the group as a whole, the average cooperation difference score (1.0) was not significantly different from zero (t(29) =1.28; p N 0.05). There was no significant difference in the cooperation difference score between self-reported “discriminators” (n= 12) and “non-discriminators” (n =18; t(28)= 0.30; p N 0.05; see Materials and methods). Nor was there a significant difference between male and female subjects (t(28) = 0.99; p N 0.05).  Post-scanning procedures and surveys  Imaging results  After being removed from the scanner, subjects provided an epithelial cell sample for subsequent genotyping analyses. In Experiment 1, subjects completed the NEO PI-R personality inventory (Costa and McCrae, 1992). In Experiment 2, subjects completed two widely used paper and pencil self-report psychopathy questionnaires (see Lilienfeld, 1998; Lilienfeld and Fowler, 2006). Results of analyses based on these questionnaires are published in a separate manuscript (Rilling et al., 2007). For both experiments, subjects completed a post-scan questionnaire that asked about strategies they employed and reactions they had to various game outcomes. Finally, all subjects were debriefed about study objectives as well as the deception used in the experiment, at  The contrast between PD trials and the non-social Gamble trials revealed activation in areas belonging to the default mode network (Table 2, Fig. 3a), including medial prefrontal and medial and lateral parietal cortices, as well as dorsolateral and rostrolateral prefrontal cortices. Although medial prefrontal activity associated with the default mode is often found both ventrally and dorsally, the medial prefrontal activation reported here had a predominantly dorsal focus, specifically in the region involved in theory-of-mind processing (Amodio and Frith, 2006). In addition to default mode areas, areas that have been linked with social cognition were activated, including bilateral anterior insula and left inferior frontal  Fig. 5. Granger causality analysis from seed in DMPFC ROI from PD–Gamble contrast for a) PD trials and b) Gamble trials. Areas that precede and cause DMPFC activity are colored green. Areas that follow and are caused by DMPFC activity are colored blue.  J.K. Rilling et al. / NeuroImage 41 (2008) 1447–1461  1455  1456  J.K. Rilling et al. / NeuroImage 41 (2008) 1447–1461  cortex (Table 2). Deactivated areas corresponded closely with the “task-positive” network that is frequently activated during attention demanding cognitive tasks and is anticorrelated with the default mode network (Fox et al., 2005; Fransson, 2005, 2006).  To determine whether the activated regions were part of a functionally connected network that was active during the PD game, the DMPFC ROI from the contrast map was used as a seed in a functional connectivity analysis that was restricted to scans acquired during PD trials. There was widespread overlap between the resulting functional connectivity map and the contrast map (Table 3, Fig. 3b). For comparison, we also generated a map of DMPFC connectivity during the gamble task (Fig. 3c). This map looked similar to the PD DMPFC map, however the latter showed more widespread connectivity with medial parietal and hippocampal cortex (Supplementary Fig. 2).  The average time course of all activated areas from the contrast map combined, excluding visual cortical areas, is plotted in Fig. 4 where it can be seen that the difference between PD and Gamble tasks arises during the fixation period that follows the decisionmaking epoch. During this epoch, activation increases for PD trials and decreases for gamble trials, and the resulting difference in activation remains for the remainder of the trial. Visual cortical areas were excluded from the plot to diminish the potentially strong influence of the visual stimulation level on the time course response in a nonspecific manner. Separate time course plots for each of the activated regions that compose the contrast map showed that for all but two of the eleven ROIs, the difference between PD and Gamble trials arose in the fixation period following the decision-making epoch (Supplementary Fig. 3). For the medial parietal cortex, the difference arose during the decisionmaking epoch itself, whereas the difference did not arise until the outcome epoch for the left anterior insula.  A Granger causality analysis was performed to attempt to track the flow of information through this network. This analysis revealed that DMPFC activity during PD trials was influenced by activation in the anterior insula and other regions that correspond well with a previously described network hypothesized to be involved with emotional salience processing (Seeley et al., 2007) (Fig. 5a;  Supplementary Fig. 1). Additionally, DMPFC activity preceded and influenced activity in a group of regions that correspond well with the executive control network, including DLPFC and lateral parietal cortices (Seeley et al., 2007). As with the functional connectivity analysis, a Granger causality image of DMPFC connectivity during the Gamble task was similar to the corresponding image during the PD task, but with subtle and potentially interesting differences (Fig. 5b). In particular, anterior insula had greater influence over DMPFC activity during PD compared with Gamble trials.  To evaluate whether components of this network were more active when interacting with in-group compared to out-group partners, activated regions from the PD–Gamble contrast in Experiment 1 were defined as ROIs to be interrogated in Experiment 2. We specifically focused on default mode regions. Four default moderelated ROIs were defined from the contrast map in Fig. 3a: DMPFC, medial parietal cortex, right and left lateral parietal cortex (i.e., TPJ). Given that previous studies have reported differential activation in the amygdala and DLPFC when evaluating faces from racial ingroups vs. out-groups, we additionally defined ROIs in these two structures (Eberhardt, 2005).  In none of these ROIs did the BOLD response to interacting with in-group partners significantly differ from that to interacting with out-group partners. However, among the 12 self-reported “discriminators”, both right TPJ and DMPFC activation was stronger for in-group than out-group partners (paired t(11) = 2.42 and 2.56, respectively p b 0.05). No other ROI showed in-group–out-group differences among discriminators (Fig. 6). Among non-discriminators, right DLPFC activation was stronger for out-group than ingroup partners (t(17) = − 2.65, p b 0.05). No other ROI showed ingroup–out-group differences among non-discriminators (Fig. 6). Time courses for each of the ROIs are shown in Supplementary Fig. 4.  Another measure of subject responsiveness to the in-group–outgroup manipulation is the difference in the number of times a subject cooperated with in-group vs. out-group partners. To explore this variability, we tested for correlations across subjects between the extent to which they behaviorally discriminated  Fig. 6. Activation within ROIs during in-group and out-group interactions, as a function of whether or not subjects reported feeling different when interacting with in-group vs. out-group partners (i.e., discriminators vs. non-discriminators).  J.K. Rilling et al. / NeuroImage 41 (2008) 1447–1461  1457  between the two groups (i.e., the difference in the number of times they chose to cooperate with in-group and out-group partners) and the extent to which activation within our ROI set differed for ingroup and out-group partners. DMPFC was the only ROI exhibiting a positive correlation between the cooperation difference score and the difference in BOLD activation between in-group and out-group partners (r = 0.36, p b 0.05).  In addition to the above ROI analyses, the cooperation difference score was also used as a covariate in a whole brain, voxelby-voxel exploratory analysis of the in-group–out-group contrast. This analysis revealed a strong negative correlation between the cooperation difference score and activation in the right frontoinsular cortex (Fig. 7a, Table 4), such that subjects who defected more with out-group than in-group partners also activated this region more for out-group than in-group partners (Fig. 7b).  Finally, we were interested in whether functional connectivity with DMPFC differed for in-group and out-group partners. As for Experiment 1, DMPFC was functionally connected with medial parietal, bilateral lateral parietal cortex, and bilateral DLPFC, when in-group and out-group data were combined (Fig. 8). DMPFC  Fig. 7. Brain areas that correlate with in-group–out-group behavior. a) Region showing a negative correlation between cooperation difference score (in-group–out-group) and the difference in brain activation (in-group– out-group). b) Scatterplot of the correlation for the region shown in a).  Table 4 Regions where the cooperation difference score (in-group–out-group) is significantly correlated with the difference in BOLD signal during in-group and out-group interactions  BA X  Y  Z  Brain region  # voxels Peak r −0.68 Right frontal operculum −0.63 Left inferior temporal gyrus Clusters of 5 or more voxels that survive a statistical threshold of p b 0.001 (r N 0.58) in a random effects analysis.  10 40 −39 −36 −10  11 13  8  20  showed stronger functional connectivity with OFC and ventral striatum when interacting with in-group compared with out-group partners (Fig. 9, Table 5).  Discussion  We have identified a network of functionally connected brain regions, including the default mode regions, that is more active when interacting with a human partner than when performing a non-social task that shares many of the same features. The default mode network or “task-negative” network has been implicated in intrinsic, self-oriented processes as opposed to extrinsic, world oriented processes (Golland et al., 2007, 2008; Gusnard et al., 2001). Within this network, activity increased during the fixation epoch that followed the choice epoch in the PD game (Fig. 4). Thus, as expected, activation of the default mode network increased during the trial epoch in which subjects were least engaged in the task. However, this only occurred in the PD task. As simulation theory would predict, this intrinsic, self-referential network is activated to a greater extent in a social task that involves making inferences about the mental states of others. The transient dip in activation following the revelation of the outcome in the PD task may reflect a brief interruption of intrinsic processing as the subject attends to the outcome, followed by a return to the intrinsic state shortly thereafter. In the Gamble task, there may not be sufficient time or motivation to transition from an extrinsic mode during the choice and outcome epochs into an intrinsic mode. That is, the need to engage in self-referential processing in order to understand the intentions of a social partner is absent from the gamble task.  The functional connectivity analysis showed marked similarity in the DMPFC connectivity network for PD and Gamble trials. However, despite this similarity, the magnitude of activation within the network is greater for the PD than the Gamble task (Figs. 3a and 4). The similarity in connectivity for the two tasks is not unexpected given that a previous study detected the default mode network both at rest and during a working memory task (Fransson, 2006). However, connectivity was attenuated in several regions during the working memory task, including medial parietal and parahippocampal cortex. Similarly, we found attenuated DMPFC connectivity with medial parietal and hippocampal cortex in the Gamble task relative to the PD task. Thus, during the PD game mentalizing may depend to a greater extent on structures involved in episodic memory retrieval (Buckner and Carroll, 2007; Cavanna and Trimble, 2006).  In addition to the default mode areas, the anterior insula was also part of the activated network. The anterior insula is involved in mapping physiological states of the body, including visceral sensations of autonomic arousal (Craig, 2002, 2003; Critchley, 2005).  1458  J.K. Rilling et al. / NeuroImage 41 (2008) 1447–1461  Fig. 8. Reproducibility of functional connectivity from DMPFC seed ROI. Results from Experiment 1 are in blue. Results from Experiment 2 are in orange.  The Granger causality analysis suggested that activity in the anterior insula as well as other regions in the emotional salience network preceded and caused the DMPFC activity during the PD Game. The influence of anterior insula on DMPFC activity in the Gamble task was attenuated compared with the PD task. Thus, autonomic arousal, in the context of a social interaction, may initiate an attempt to understand another person's mental state. Bilateral DLPFC was also part of the network, and the Granger analysis suggested that it followed and was caused by DMPFC activity. DLPFC is part of an executive control network (Seeley  et al., 2007). One possible interpretation of this result is that the attempt to understand another person's mental state is followed by an attempt to regulate one's emotional response to that inference and/or to use that knowledge in strategic decision-making. However, given that DLPFC is associated with many functions in addition to these, this interpretation should be considered speculative at this time.  All four of the default mode regions from our network have been implicated in theory-of-mind reasoning. These include the medial parietal cortex, bilateral lateral parietal cortex (or temporoparietal junction) and DMPFC (Mitchell et al., 2005, 2006; Saxe and Wexler, 2005). If the default mode is involved in simulating  Table 5 DMPFC connectivity with in-group – DMPFC connectivity with out-group  Brain region  BA  X  Y  Z  # voxels Peak t  47 11 11  Right inferior frontal gyrus 3.88 Right orbital gyrus 3.28 Right orbital gyrus 3.48 Right ventral striatum 4.85 Left orbital gyrus 4.34 Left cingulate gyrus -3.63 Left orbital gyrus 3.97 Left inferior frontal gyrus 3.29 Left inferior frontal gyrus 3.78 Left inferior temporal gyrus -3.44 Clusters of 5 or more voxels that survive a statistical threshold of p b 0.005 (t N 3.05).  11 32 10, 11 47 10 37  39 13 20 153 134 11 55 6 18 5  33 15 15 -21 -16 -3 -14 -30 -35 -47  29 55 20 15 11 3 44 32 46 -56  6 -2 -7 -9 -9 40 -3 -5 2 -16  Fig. 9. Regions showing stronger functional connectivity with DMPFC during in-group vs. out-group runs.  J.K. Rilling et al. / NeuroImage 41 (2008) 1447–1461  1459  the mental perspective of others, we might expect it to be more active when the subject is interacting with an in-group partner who is like them and can therefore be more easily simulated, compared to an out-group partner (Mitchell et al., 2005). Looking at the subgroup of subjects who reported that the in-group–out-group manipulation was effective, this was true for two of the ROIs, DMPFC and right TPJ. In each of these ROIs, the BOLD signal increased during the fixation epoch that followed the decisionmaking epoch, after which the response to in-group partners was consistently above the response to out-group partners (Supplementary Fig. 4). Further evidence that the difference in DMPFC activation between in-group and out-group partners was more pronounced when the behavioral manipulation was more effective is provided by the positive correlation between the cooperation difference score (in-group–out-group) and the difference in DMPFC activation when playing with in-group vs. out-group partners. This was not true of right TPJ.  If DMPFC is involved in simulation, that is, understanding others through imagining our own thoughts, feelings or behaviors in a similar situation (Iacoboni et al., 2005), we would expect it to also be active when subjects are asked to reflect on their own thoughts and feelings. Indeed, this region of DMPFC is activated by tasks in which subjects indicate whether a picture makes them feel pleasant or unpleasant and when they report their own views on various personal and social issues (Gusnard et al., 2001; Mitchell et al., 2006). However, one investigation that explicitly tested simulation theory by asking people to reflect on the thoughts of similar and dissimilar others, found DMPFC to be more responsive to dissimilar compared with similar others; the exact opposite prediction of simulation theory (Mitchell et al., 2006). Yet, a slightly more ventral region of medial prefrontal cortex had the opposite response properties, in line with simulation theory. When we apply these two ROIs (10 mm cubes centered on the activation peaks in each region) to our data, there is no significant difference in the response to ingroup and out-group partners, for discriminators, non-discriminators or the group as a whole (p N 0.05). The explanation for the discrepancy between the DMPFC results reported here and those of Mitchell et al. is uncertain, however one factor to consider is the nature of the tasks used in the two experiments. In the present experiment, subjects are immersed in a dynamic social interaction in which they are likely to be continually updating predictions of their partner's future behavior based on partner feedback. On the other hand, in the study by Mitchell et al., subjects build a mental model of a person based on a written description and then use that information to estimate the subjects' views on a wide range of personal and social issues, without receiving behavioral feedback from the partner.  We also found that DMPFC exhibited stronger functional connectivity with OFC and ventral striatum when interacting with ingroup compared with out-group partners. Both the ventral striatum and OFC are involved in processing rewarding stimuli (O'Doherty, 2004). Thus, increased connectivity with these limbic regions could indicate stronger positive emotional influences for in-group interactions. Indeed, analysis of post-scan emotion ratings showed that subjects reported significantly higher levels of camaraderie in response to mutual cooperation with in-group compared with out-group partners (Two way, repeated measures F 1,26=12.6, pb 0.001; Supplementary Fig. 5). Among non-discriminators, DLPFC was more active when interacting with out-group than in-group partners. Previous studies have reported DLPFC activation when evaluating faces from racial out-groups, which has been interpreted as a neural correlate of cognitive effort to inhibit a prepotent discriminatory tendency  those subjects who exert more cognitive effort  (Eberhardt, 2005). Thus, our data could be interpreted to suggest that towards overcoming biases against out-group partners may be more successful at doing so, or at least more likely to report that they were successful.  Finally, a whole brain, voxel-by-voxel exploratory analysis revealed that subjects who defected more with out-group than ingroup partners also activated the frontoinsular cortex more for outgroup than in-group partners (Fig. 7b). Activation in this region has been observed in response to a variety of negative social interactions, from social exclusion in a cyberball task (Eisenberger et al., 2003), to receiving an unfair offer in an Ultimatum Game (Sanfey et al., 2003), to watching a loved one receive a painful stimulus (Singer et al., 2004). Thus, the correlation could indicate that subjects who defect more with out-group compared to in-group partners find their out-group interactions particularly aversive relative to their in-group interactions. However, insula activation could also be the cause rather than the effect of an aversive social interaction. Viewing pictures of out-groups that are both stereotypically hostile and stereotypically incompetent activates the anterior insula (Harris and Fiske, 2006), and the right anterior insula, in particular, is thought to be a site of interoceptive awareness that gives rise to subjective feeling states that may play a role in decisionmaking (Damasio, 1994). Thus, subjects with strong initial ingroup–out-group biases may activate anterior insula more when playing with out-group partners and this, in turn, may bias them to defect more often with out-group partners.  In summary, our social interactive task was associated with activation in a network of functionally connected brain regions. Several nodes in this network are components of the default mode network that typically deactivates to attention demanding tasks. The fact that these regions activate to an attention demanding social task suggests that the tonic, resting state activity in default mode regions may be involved in social cognition (Buckner and Carroll, 2007). This social cognitive neural network also included anterior insular cortex which appears to initiate engagement of the network. For subjects in whom the in-group–out–group manipulation was more effective, activation in DMPFC was stronger for in– group vs. out-group interactions, supporting the simulation theory of mentalizing. DMPFC also exhibited stronger connectivity with limbic, reward regions for in-group compared with out-group interactions, and subjects reported more camaraderie following CC outcomes in the former. On the other hand, subjects reporting that they did not discriminate showed stronger DLPFC activation during out-group interactions, suggesting that they may have been exerting cognitive effort to override discriminatory tendencies. Finally, subjects who behaviorally discriminated against out-group partners to a greater extent also showed stronger activation in the frontoinsular cortex during out-group interactions, implying that these interactions were particularly arousing and perhaps aversive. These differences in brain activity for in-group and out-group interactions are potential neural substrates for the human tendency to more readily identify with in-group members and more readily distrust, fear and discriminate against out-group members. Sci. 16, 56–63.  Neuron  Article  Social Manipulation of Preference in the Human Brain  Keise Izuma1,* and Ralph Adolphs1 1Division of Humanities and Social Sciences, California Institute of Technology, 1200 E. California Boulevard, Pasadena, CA 91125, USA *Correspondence: izuma@caltech.edu http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.neuron.2013.03.023  SUMMARY  Our preferences are inﬂuenced by what other people like, but depend critically on how we feel about those people, a classical psychological effect called ‘‘cognitive balance.’’ Here, we manipulated preferences for goods by telling participants the preferences of strongly liked or disliked groups of other people. Participants’ preferences converged to those of the liked group, but diverged from the disliked group. Activation of dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (dmPFC) tracked the discrepancy between one’s own preference and its social ideal and was associated with subsequent preference change (toward the liked and away from the disliked group), even several months later. A follow-up study found overlapping activation in this same region of dmPFC with negative monetary outcomes, but no overlap with nearby activations induced by response conﬂict. A single social encounter can thus result in long-lasting preference change, a mechanism that recruits dmPFC and that may reﬂect the aversive nature of cognitive imbalance.  INTRODUCTION  Our preferences for goods are inﬂuenced by what other people prefer (Cialdini and Goldstein, 2004). As the internet has become pervasive, we are often exposed to information about what is popular among a certain group of people (e.g., one’s friends, one’s school, people in other countries, and so forth). Having preferences that are different from those of people we like and having preferences that are similar to those of people that we dislike are both undesirable. One would therefore expect that we change our preferences not only to be more similar to those of people we like, but also to be more dissimilar to those of people we dislike, an effect with a long history in social psychology dubbed ‘‘cognitive balance’’ (Heider, 1946, 1958). Since the theory was proposed more than ﬁve decades ago, it has stimulated a huge number of studies (see Abelson et al., 1968; Gawronski and Strack, 2012; Insko, 1984; Zajonc, 1968), and, because of the theory’s wide applications, it has remained strongly inﬂuential across all of social psychology (see Greenwald et al., 2002; Walther and Weil, 2012). Although there have been several recent investigations of the neural mechanisms  underlying how our preferences are inﬂuenced by the opinions of others in general (i.e., social conformity) (Berns et al., 2010; Campbell-Meiklejohn et al., 2010; Campbell-Meiklejohn et al., 2012a, 2012b; Klucharev et al., 2009, 2011; Zaki et al., 2011), it remains unknown how the brain incorporates our attitude toward other people into such inﬂuence, and whether such effects are transient or more permanent. Elucidating a speciﬁc neural mechanism to explain the ubiquitous effect of other people’s opinions on our own preferences is of high relevance also for marketing and advertising, and would importantly inform classical social psychology theories that are based on our need to maximize cognitive consistency and congruency (Abelson et al., 1968; Festinger, 1957; Gawronski and Strack, 2012; Greenwald et al., 2002; Heider, 1946, 1958; Osgood and Tannenbaum, 1955).  To investigate how people’s preferences are inﬂuenced by those of others, we used the framework of balance theory (Heider, 1946, 1958), which states that our preferences for objects change so as to become similar to the preferences of people we like, and dissimilar to the preferences of people we dislike (Figure 1). In balance theory, balance depends on a triadic relationship between self, another person(s), and an object being evaluated (Figure 1A). A triadic relationship includes three attitudes: (1) one’s attitude toward the other person, (2) one’s attitude toward the object, and (3) the other person’s attitude toward the same object. A balanced triad occurs when all the attitudes are positive, or two are negative and one is positive (for example, two individuals have a negative attitude toward an object, but they like each other). If a state is imbalanced, an individual is motivated to change one of their attitudes (either about the other person, or about the object) in order to restore balance (Heider, 1946, 1958).  In the present study, regional brain activation was measured with BOLD-fMRI while participants (n = 18) rated their preferences for t-shirts (n = 174; Figures 1B and 1C), saw other people’s preferences for the same t-shirts (Figure 1D), and then re-evaluated the t-shirts a second time. Critically, we employed two groups of other people, validated to be strongly liked or disliked (see the Supplemental Information available online for details): in some trials, participants were given feedback about how their fellow students rated the t-shirt (‘‘students’’; liked group), whereas in other trials, they found out how sex offenders rated it (‘‘offenders’’; disliked group). A further question of interest was whether the preference changes induced by cognitive imbalance in our study might persist. Four months after the fMRI study, we therefore asked participants (15/18) to rate the same t-shirts a third time.  Neuron 78, 563–573, May 8, 2013 ª2013 Elsevier Inc. 563  The Neural Correlates of Cognitive Balance  Neuron  Lieberman, 2004), as well as by demands for cognitive control (e.g., response conﬂict) (Botvinick et al., 2001). Several theories of pMFC function proposed to account for these diverse ﬁndings (Alexander and Brown, 2011; Botvinick, 2007; Botvinick et al., 2001; Holroyd and Coles, 2002; Rushworth et al., 2004; Yeung et al., 2004) all agree on an important role in detecting changes in the environment (especially negative ones including unfavorable outcomes and response conﬂict) that entail subsequent behavioral adjustment (Botvinick et al., 2001; Eisenberger and Lieberman, 2004; Holroyd and Coles, 2002; Ridderinkhof et al., 2004; Shackman et al., 2011; Ullsperger et al., 2004). It was also recently proposed that pMFC may be a key area in inducing palliative responses following various types of inconsistency described in social psychological theories (Proulx et al., 2012). While this idea of pMFC function generally ﬁts well with balance theory, we nonetheless used a whole-brain approach in our initial analyses.  To provide initial insight into the neural processes corresponding to the hypothesized pMFC activation underlying balance theory, we also had our subjects complete two independent localizer tasks known from prior studies to activate sectors of this region. It could be argued (Harmon-Jones, 2004) that cognitive imbalance constitutes a type of cognitive conﬂict, recruiting the pMFC for the same reason that this region is activated in simple speeded-response tasks such as Stroop or ﬂanker tasks: the simultaneous activation of incompatible response representations (response conﬂict) (Botvinick et al., 2001). The other possibility, as originally stated in balance theory (Heider, 1958), is that cognitive imbalance might simply be aversive, recruiting the pMFC as a form of negative feedback or aversive outcome (Miltner et al., 1997; Ullsperger and von Cramon, 2003). These two possibilities may reﬂect functional dissociations mapping to anatomically distinct sectors of the pMFC (Hikosaka and Isoda, 2010; Ridderinkhof et al., 2004; Rushworth et al., 2004). To provide further insight, we used two independent localizer tasks to identify, within pMFC, areas previously implicated in processing response conﬂict (using the Multi-Source Interference Task or MSIT) (Bush and Shin, 2006) and areas involved in processing aversive outcomes (using the Monetary Incentive Delay Task or MIDT) (Knutson et al., 2000).  RESULTS  Behavioral Results: Impression Ratings From the multiple attitude ratings that participants gave about the two social groups, all endorsed a positive attitude toward their fellow students at the California Institute of Technology (Caltech) (mean rating = 9.23) but a strongly negative attitude toward sex offenders (mean = 1.85, on a scale from 1 to 14). The difference in the impression ratings between two groups was highly signiﬁcant (t(17) = 12.9, p < 0.001).  Behavioral Results: The Effect of Cognitive Imbalance on Preference Participants’ preferences for the t-shirts changed as predicted by balance theory (Heider, 1946, 1958): toward the preferences of the student group and away from those of the offender group (Figure 2A). Speciﬁcally, subjects’ preferences for t-shirts they  Figure 1. Balance Theory and Experimental Protocol (A) Arrows represent the direction of evaluation together with indicated valence (+, like; –, dislike). Any imbalanced state has an odd number of negative (–) attitudes. The ﬁgure shows an example of an imbalanced state (e.g., one negative attitude) that would motivate a change in one’s evaluation of the object (toward increased preference in this example). (B) Present experiment. Participants were students at the California Institute of Technology (Caltech). Their attitude toward others was manipulated by using a validated liked group (fellow Caltech students) and disliked group (sex offenders). Participants rated their preferences for t-shirts and were subsequently given feedback about the other group’s preferences for the same t-shirts. (C) During the ﬁrst preference-rating task, subjects rated 174 t-shirt designs using a 14 point scale. Immediately after rating a t-shirt, subjects viewed their own preference and the preference of one of the two groups (either Caltech students or sex offenders), dichotomized as liked or disliked. Thumbs-up corresponded to ratings R8 and thumbs-down to ratings %7 on the 14 point scale. (D) Eight possible combinations of subjects’ preference and others’ preference (plus two control conditions). Four of them represent imbalanced states (highlighted by red squares) according to balance theory.  We hypothesized that posterior medial frontal cortex (pMFC), which includes dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC), dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (dmPFC), and presupplementary motor area (pre-SMA), plays a key role in representing imbalanced states and subsequent preference change. The pMFC is activated by a variety of aversive outcomes (Hikosaka and Isoda, 2010; Ridderinkhof et al., 2004; Shackman et al., 2011), including monetary loss (O’Doherty et al., 2003), reduced reward (Bush et al., 2002; Shima and Tanji, 1998) and negative feedback (Jocham et al., 2009; Miltner et al., 1997; Ullsperger and von Cramon, 2003), error detection (Falkenstein et al., 1991; Holroyd and Coles, 2002), physical and social pain (Eisenberger and  564 Neuron 78, 563–573, May 8, 2013 ª2013 Elsevier Inc.  Neuron  The Neural Correlates of Cognitive Balance  initially disliked increased after they learned that other students liked or offenders disliked the same items, whereas their preferences for t-shirts they initially liked decreased after they learned that students disliked or offenders liked the same items. This was borne out by a 2 (group) 3 2 (self-preference) 3 2 (other preference) repeated-measures ANOVA showing a signiﬁcant groupby-other preference interaction (F(1,17) = 9.41, p = 0.007).  As preferences were rated using a 14 point scale (see Experimental Procedures for details), the degree of cognitive  Figure 2. Preference Change and dmPFC Activation Induced by Cognitive Imbalance (A) Self-reported preference change between second and ﬁrst ratings. Red arrows indicate imbalanced conditions. See also Figures S1 and S2. (B) dmPFC regions signiﬁcantly correlated with the degree of cognitive imbalance (Cognitive Imbalance Index; CII) in each trial. See also Figures S3 and S4. (C) Breakdown of activation patterns in dmPFC during the feedback period of the ﬁrst preferencerating tasks. See also Figure S6.  imbalance in each trial could be quantiﬁed parametrically as the difference between a participant’s ratings and the (binary) preference of the other group (Cognitive Imbalance Index [CII] ranging from 0 to 13; see Experimental Procedures; Table S1). Thus, the greater the difference between self-ratings and student preferences, or the smaller the difference between self-ratings and offender preferences, the greater the CII. To test whether larger CIIs motivate greater preference change as hypothesized by balance theory (Heider, 1946, 1958), we conducted linear regressions, separately for each group (students, offenders), with preference change (second ratings – ﬁrst ratings) as the dependent variable and the signed CII as the predictor variable (see Experimental Procedures for details). CII signiﬁcantly predicted subsequent preference change for both groups (p < 0.001), and there was no signiﬁcant difference between the effect of the two groups (p = 0.41, not signiﬁcant; Figure S1A). All effects remained signiﬁcant when including the raw ﬁrst rating as a separate regressor, to account for any possible effects of regression to the mean (see Supplemental Information; Figure S2 for details).  Remarkably, subjects’ preferences remained socially inﬂuenced even after several months had passed. We observed the same signiﬁcant group-by-other preference interaction (F(1,14) = 9.15, p = 0.009), and the CII signiﬁcantly predicted subjects’ preferences for both groups after 4 months (Figures S1B and S1C). Overall, the ﬁndings suggest that a qualitatively similar mechanism operates to represent cognitive imbalance evoked by both liked and disliked groups of other people, notably recruiting the dmPFC.  Association between Brain Activation and Preference Change Activation of pMFC has been associated with behavioral adjustment following negative or unexpected outcomes (Bush et al., 2002; Jocham et al., 2009; O’Doherty et al., 2003; Ridderinkhof et al., 2004; Shima and Tanji, 1998; Ullsperger et al., 2004). As the CII in our study is signiﬁcantly associated both with subsequent preference change as well as activation within speciﬁc brain regions (Table 1), it naturally follows that activations in these regions should also be associated with preference change. To show this, we pooled the within-subject correlation between brain activation and preference change across the eight experimental conditions of interest (see Figure 1D). Among all brain regions identiﬁed above, the dmPFC showed the strongest association between CII-evoked activation and subsequent behavioral preference change (Figure 3A; Table 2). Our analysis thus conﬁrmed that the higher the dmPFC activation when viewing others’ preference for the same item, the larger the subsequent preference change in the direction predicted by balance theory (Heider, 1946, 1958).  The association between dmPFC activation during the initial fMRI experiment and later preference change also remained signiﬁcant even after 4 months (Figure 3B), and the dmPFC was the only region that survived a correction for multiple comparisons across both time points (initial change and 4 months later; see Table 2). This showed activation in pMFC, especially in dmPFC (Figure 2B), as well as left insula, left inferior frontal gyrus (IFG), and posterior cingulate cortex (PCC) (see Table 1; Figure S3). A further quantiﬁcation of this ﬁnding was provided by a region of interest (ROI) analysis that found that the dmPFC region showed particularly increased activation in conditions featuring cognitive imbalance, and a signiﬁcant three-way interaction (group 3 self-preference 3 other preference; F(1,17) = 19.7, p < 0.001) (Figure 2C) that paralleled the behavioral ﬁndings described above. These results conﬁrm that dmPFC activation in our task depends on a triadic relationship between self, other, and an object of shared evaluation, providing a direct neural correlate of cognitive imbalance according to balance theory (Heider, 1946, 1958). Left insula and left IFG also showed the same three-way interaction (p < 0.01), whereas PCC did not (p = 0.83, not signiﬁcant) (see Figure S3). As a conﬁrmatory analysis, when we directly explored the three-way interaction contrast (i.e., imbalance versus balance contrast), signiﬁcant activations were found in dmPFC and left IFG (see Figure S4A). There was no region signiﬁcantly negatively correlated with the CII. However, when the four balanced conditions were compared with the four imbalanced conditions, we found significant activation in ventral striatum, consistent with prior reports (Campbell-Meiklejohn et al., 2010; Klucharev et al., 2009). Furthermore, this striatal area overlapped with the region sensitive to reward that was identiﬁed by our MIDT (Figures S4B and S4C), consistent with the hypothesis that not only agreeing with liked others (Campbell-Meiklejohn et al., 2010; Klucharev et al., 2009), but also disagreeing with disliked others may both be rewarding. Right insula and right IFG were also activated in this contrast Informationfor details).
